En la actualidad ya es conocida por sus clientes, que a diario acude a su empresa a vender y comprar productos agrícolas y es ella quien personalmente les atiende  con el carisma que le caracteriza.

Con el préstamo de S/ 2,500.00, desea invertirlo comprando granos como maíz, soya, maní y otros productos industrializados como  harina de pescado, polvillo de arroz todo esto en sacos y toneladas

Anatolia, hoy en día se siente una mujer muy realizada, con más ganas de seguir adelante. Agradece a Manuela Ramos por ayudarla a implementar más su negocio y también a muchas mujeres que  quieren crecer empresarial.
texts.en:
Anatolia belongs to the Virgin of Mercedes Cooperative Bank. She lives on Eduardo Peña Street in the Juanjui district, in the Mariscal Cáceres province of San Martín. She is married, 33 years old, and the mother of 3 small children who are still in school. Anatolia has dedicated herself to the purchase and sale of grains for several years and, together with her family, they have managed to get ahead. She tells us that she feels good about what she does; she has a large location where she can store her products. She is currently well known to her customers, who visit her enterprise on a daily basis to sell and buy agricultural products. She personally attends to them, with the charisma that is so characteristic of her. She wants to use the loan of 2,500 soles to invest in the purchase of grains such as corn, soy, peanuts, and processed goods such as fish flour and rice dust, by the sack or ton. These days Anatolia feels like an accomplished woman, with an even greater desire to get ahead. She thanks Manuela Ramos for helping her expand her business more, and also the many women who want to grow business-wise.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To by corn, cacao and peanuts in sacks.

loans.name: Lili

texts.es:
La señora Lili, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres Luchadoras”, vive en el Jr. Santa Eufrasia Nº 559, Distrito de Tarapoto, departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 57 años y es madre de 05 hijos, todos ya independientes.

Lleva años ya dedicándose a este tipo de actividad, con la venta de pollos desviscerados.
Nos cuenta que anteriormente vendía solo en una mesita, balanza y sus pollos, y con su primer prestamo en Manuela Ramos de S/. 300.00, compro una paragua y una balanza moderna, para brindar mas confianza y mejor servicio a sus clientes y moradores de la comunidad. 

En la actualidad, continua con el mismo negocio, en un puesto alquilado del Mercado Central, donde brinda el servicio a los moradores de la comunidad y amas de casa.
Con este préstamo de S/. 2,200.00,  comprara  pollos vivos en jabas, además parte del dinero lo invertirá implementando y mejorando su ambiente de trabajo.

Hoy, se siente mas independiente y segura, ya que es ella quien toma sus propias decisiones en su negocio y en los ingresos que genera.
Lili, manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por darle la oportunidad de poner en práctica sus habilidades para el negocio y desarrollarse como mujer.
texts.en:
Lili belongs to the Fighting Women Cooperative Bank, and lives on Santa Eufrasia Street in the Tarapoto district of San Martín. She is single, 57 years old, and the mother of 5 children who now live on their own. She has dedicated herself to the sale of butchered chickens for many years now. She tells us that she previously sold her products with only a small table, a scale, and her chickens. With her first loan of 300 soles from Manuela Ramos, she bought an umbrella and a modern scale. This allows her to provide better service to her local customers. She is currently continuing in the same type of business located in a rented stall at the Central Market. Here, she sells to the community members and homemakers. With this loan of 2,200 soles, she will buy live chickens in crates. Also, another part of the funds will be invested into implementation and improvement of her workplace. Today, she feels more independent and secure, as she makes her own decisions about her business and the income she generates. Lili expresses her gratitude to Manuela Ramos for giving her the opportunity to put her abilities into practice for the business and to grow as a woman.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in buying chickens in crates.

loans.name: Maria Esther

texts.es:
La señora Maria Esther, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Micaela Bastidas”, vive en el Jr. Prolongación La Merced Nº 316 – Distrito D. Juanjui, Provincia D. Mariscal Cáceres, Departamento D. San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 70 años y es madre D. 08 hijos, todos ya independientes y con familia ya constituida..

Ah Maria, le encanta trabajar, y a pesar D. su edad, se siente con ganas D. seguir adelante, se dedica a la venta D. viseras D. ganado vacuno y chancho, en este negocio también su esposo es quien la ayuda, cuenta también con una chacra donD. cría sus animales: chanchos y ganados.                                               
En la actualidad continua con el mismo negocio ubicado en su propia casa, donD. sus principales clientes son los vecinos y amigo D. su barrio.

Con este préstamo D. S/. 2,000.00 comprará  un ganado vacuno para sacrificarlo en el camal y vender su carne y vísceras en kilos. 

Hoy se siente muy feliz del servicio que brinda y agradece a Manuela Ramos por apoyar a mujeres como ella que quieren trabajar y salir adelante, espera que sigan así por mucho tiempo y ayuden a muchas mujeres emprendedoras.
texts.en:
Maria Esther belongs to the “Micaela Bastidas” Cooperative Bank. She lives on La Merced Street, in the Juanjui district of the Mariscal Cáceres province, in San Martín. She is married, 70 years old, and the mother of 8 children who are now living independently and have their own families. Maria loves to work and, despite her age, yearns to continue to get ahead. She dedicates herself to selling cow and pig entrails, and her husband helps her with the business. She also has a farm where she raises her animals: pigs and livestock. She currently continues in the same line of business, which she runs out of her house. Her main customers are neighbors and friends in the area. With this loan of 2,000 soles, she will buy a cow to butcher and sell its meat and entrails by the kilo. Today, she feels very content with the service she provides and thanks Manuela Ramos for supporting women like her that want to work and progress. She hopes that they will continue like this for a long time, and help many women entrepreneurs.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a cow.

loans.name: Mari Rosabeth

texts.es:
La señora Mari Rosabeth, pertenece al Banco Comunal “El Abiseo”, vive en el Jr. Prolog. Sargento Lores  Nº 141, Distrito de Juanjui, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 38 años y es madre de 2 hijos, que aun dependen de ella.

Mari, se inicio con S/. 500.00 y por iniciativa propia fue quien decidió emprender su negocio de venta de abarrotes, empezó primero con pocos productos para vender, luego fue implementando mas su negocio, ahora vende mas y ya es conocida por sus clientes, vecinos y amigos.
En la actualidad continúa con el mismo negocio, cuenta con un local especialmente  acondicionado en su propia casa, donde atiende a sus clientes con amabilidad y el buen carisma que tiene.

Con el prestamo de S/. 1,000.0 lo invertirá comprando más productos para surtir su negocio como arroz y azúcar en sacos, papel higiénico en paquete, leche y conservas de pescado en cajas, insumos para el aseo personal y limpieza del hogar, y también útiles escolares como lapiceros, lápices, plumones, correctores, borradores, cartulinas y productos variados para mantener contenta a su clientela.

Ella, toma las decisiones en las ganancias de su negocio. En lo personal, nos cuenta que es una mujer muy luchadora y constante en sus metas que desea lograr y responsable con el pago de sus cuotas. 
 
Mari, esta muy agradecida con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como empresaria y Mujer, así mismo ayudar a muchas mujeres que quieren salir a delante.
texts.en:
Mari Rosabeth belongs to the “El Abiseo” Cooperative Bank, and lives on Sargento Lores Street in the Juanjui district of San Martín. She is married, 38 years old, and the mother of 2 children who still depend on her financially. Maria started with 500 soles and, through her own initiative, decided to start her business selling groceries. She started with just a few items to sell, and later began expanding her business more. She now sells many products, and is well known to her customers, neighbors, and friends. She currently continues in this business, and has set aside and outfitted an area in her own home where she tends to her customers with her friendly and charismatic nature. She plans to invest the loan of 1,000 soles into purchasing more products such as rice and sugar, toilet paper, milk, canned fish, personal hygiene products, cleaning supplies for the home, and also school supplies such as pens, pencils, magic markers, erasers, poster board, and varied products to keep her customers happy. She makes the decisions regarding her business’ earnings. On the personal side, she tells us she is a hard-working woman who keeps sight of her goals to succeed and be responsible with her loan payments. Mari is very grateful to the Manuela Ramos movement for helping her grow as an entrepreneur and woman, as well as for assisting many women who want to get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to supply her general store.

loans.name: Tedoro Giovanni

texts.es: Teodoro Giovanni Q. D. tiene 42 años de edad, es un hombre casado y tiene 2 hijos menores de edad. Su actividad económica es una pulpería la cual surge como una nueva fuente de ingreso para su familia. Este le ha permitido mejorar un poco su calidad de vida y brindarle un trabajo a su esposa en el mismo hogar lo que permite estar al cuidado de los niños el mayor tiempo posible ha  sufrido mucho con el alza de los precios en los productos y es por esto que solicita a Fundación León 2000 un financiamiento de manera que le permita comprar productos por mayor a un menor precio y asi ofrecerle a sus clientes un precio justo. Los de seos del son aumentar sus ventas y mantener el núcleo familiar estable en todos los ámbitos.
texts.en:
Teodoro Giovanni Q. D. is 42 years old, married, and has 2 small children. His economic activity is a general store that serves as a new source of income for his family, which has helped him improve their standard of living somewhat. It also provides work for his wife within the home, allowing her to care for their children. He has suffered the most because of high prices, which is why he requests financing from Fundación León 2000. He could then buy products at lower wholesale cost and, in turn, sell them to his customers at fair prices. His wishes are to increase sales and to maintain a stable family nucleus in all areas.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Martha Maria

texts.es:
La señora Martha, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Manos Unidas”, vive en el Jr. Jorge Chávez Nº 495, Distrito de Juanjui, Departamento de San Martín. Es Viuda, tiene 50 años y es madre de 02 hijos, quienes ya tiene su propias familias.

Lleva ya varios años dedicándose al rubro de alquiler de cuartos, nos cuenta que se inicio con S/. 1,000.00 y en aquel tiempo contó con el apoyo de su esposo y juntos decidieron dedicarse a este negocio.
Nos cuenta que le va muy bien, en la actualidad tiene 7 cuartos en alquiler ubicada en su misma casa.

Con el préstamo de S/1,000.00, lo invertirá comprando ladrillos, cementos, triplay, para la construcción de mas dormitorios, al fondo de su casa.

Ella es quien toma las decisiones en las ganancias de su negocio, en lo personal, se siente más independiente, segura y capaz.

Marthita; manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por hacer posible que pueda asegurar su vejez generando sus propios ingresos.
texts.en:
Martha is a member of the Manos Unidas ("Hands Together") Village Bank. She lives on Jorge Chavez Street, in Juanjui District, San Martin Department. She is 50 years old, widowed and has two children, who are both adults with families of their own. Martha has been renting out rooms for years. Back when her husband was still alive and supported her, they made a joint decision to get into this business. She started out with just 1000 soles. Today, she is doing very well for herself, and is renting out seven rooms in her home. Martha will use this loan of 1000 soles to buy bricks, cement and wood laminate to build more bedrooms in back of her house. She makes her own decisions in her personal life and when it comes to her business and how she will spend her profits, which makes her feel independent, capable and safe. Martha is grateful to Manuela Ramos for allowing her to provide for her old age by generating her own income.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy construction materials to build more rooms to rent

loans.name: Raquel

texts.es:
La señora Raquel, pertenece al Banco Comunal “El Abiseo”, vive en el Jr. Eduardo Peña Meza cdra. 01, Distrito de Juanjui, Provincia Marisca Cáceres, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 39 años y es madre de 05 hijos, 04 que aun dependen de ella y que también la apoyan en el negocio cuando ella no se encuentra.

Tiene varios años dedicándose a este tipo de actividad, de venta de pollos desviscerados, se encuentra ubicada en el Mercado Central de la Ciudad. Se inicio con el primer prestamo de Manuela Ramos, vendiendo pocos pollos, luego tuvo mucha acogida y clientes fuertes.
Así, siguió superándose, ahora vende pollos en cantidad a esto lo agregó la   vende patos desviscerados que los cría y cuando tiene pedidos los sacrifica y luego los vende.
En la actualidad, continua con el mismo negocio, en un puesto alquilado del Mercado Central, donde brinda el servicio, a los moradores de la comunidad y amas de casa.  Con su préstamo de S/.3,000.00,  comprara  pollos vivos en jabas y  parte del dinero lo invertirá comprando herramientas nuevas como una balanza digital para remplazar a la que ahora tiene.

Hoy, es una mujer independiente, y ella es la que administra y toma las decisiones en su negocio.
Raquel Dice: Que el pertenecer a un grupo de mujeres le ha ayudado a conocer mejor sus derechos y juntas  hacer que estas sean respetadas.
texts.en:
Señora Raquel is a member of the “El Abiseo” Community Bank. She lives in the first block on Eduardo Peña Meza Street, in the district of Juanjui, Marisca Cáceres province, San Martín department. She is 39 years old, lives with her partner, and has five children. She still supports four of the children, and they help out in the business when she is busy elsewhere. Raquel has been selling poultry for several years in the Central Market of the city. She started out with her first loan with Kiva Partner, Manuela Ramos, selling only a few chickens, but her business became widely known and she now has regular customers. In this way she has succeeded and now sells many chickens as well as ducks. The ducks she raises herself and when customers put in an order, she slaughters the ducks and sells them. Currently she works from a stall rented in the Central Market, with local inhabitants and housewives as her customers. With part of the S/.3,000 loan, she will buy live chickens in crates, and with the other part she will purchase new equipment such as digital scales to replace what she has now. Today Raquel is an independent woman who runs her own business and makes all the decisions. She says that belonging to a group of women has helped her to understand her rights and together they make other people respect them.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase chickens in crates and new digital scales

loans.name: Julio

texts.es:
Julio Mairena es un caballero muy esforzado que se dedica a su negocio de de abarrotería ofreciendo los diferentes productos como lo son granos básicos tales como arroz, azúcar y frijoles.

El señor Mairena ha dado parte de su vida a este trabajo y está muy consciente en que su negocio hoy más que nunca necesita desarrollarse para mejorar su condición de vida y la de su familia. Es por esto que ha acudido a Ceprodel para obtener un crédito para la compra de los granos básicos y así continuar mejorando en su negocio que tanto requiere de su apoyo.
texts.en:
Julio Mairena is a determined man who works in a grocery selling a variety of staples such as rice, sugar, and beans. He has dedicated part of his life to this work. He is very aware that today more than ever his business needs to expand so that he can improve his and his family’s lives. He went to Kiva partner, Ceprodel, to obtain a loan with which to buy more staples and in this way continue improving his business which needs so much support.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase basic food staples

loans.name: María Verónica

texts.es:
En Managua capital del bello país de Nicaragua, la señora María C. se dedica a comercializar los productos de ropa, chinelas y objetos personales como prensa pelos, aretes, entre otros siendo este su negocio el cual le brinda las condiciones para desarrollarse.

Ella, hoy en día ha acudido a Ceprodel para obtener un crédito para la compra de los productos ya que los requiere con mucha urgencia y para ello espera con mucho entusiasmo en que su crédito será aprobado y procederá a la compra de dicha mercadería para comercializarla.
texts.en:
Señora María C. works in Managua, the capital of the beautiful country of Nicaragua, selling clothes, footwear, and personal items such as hair clips and earrings. Her business is ready for development. Today she went to Kiva partner, Ceprodel, to obtain a loan to buy products which she urgently needs. She is waiting with much enthusiasm for the loan to be approved so she can proceed with the purchase of these products and begin selling them.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy products

loans.name: Paula

texts.es:
La señora Paula pertenece al banco comunal “Las Fronterizas”,  del distrito de Desaguadero, Provincia de Chucuito, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 36 años de edad, y es madre de 03 hijos, con estudios de secundaria incompleta (tercer grado de secundaria). 
Trabaja con el movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 8 años, inicio su negocio de venta de golosinas con S/. 300.00 nuevos soles como capital inicial.
En la actualidad su negocio viene superando la demanda proyectada, por ello requiere un capital adicional de S/. 2000.00 soles para aumentar su mercadería y comprar golosinas, gaseosas, galletas, enlatados frescos, etc., con la mira de convertirse en distribuidora al por mayor y con ello obtener mejores ingresos para ayudar a su familia, 
Su sueño es tener una tienda grande y bien surtida, así podría distribuir al por mayor.
texts.en:
Paula belongs to the Las Fronterizas community bank in the Desaguadero district, Chucuito Province, Puno department. She is 36 and has three children. She went to high school for three years. She has worked with the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for eight years. She started her business of selling sweets with 300 PEN as her initial capital. Currently her business is going very well and demand for her products have exceeded her projections, therefore she needs additional capital for 2,000 PEN to increase her merchandise and buy candy, sodas, cookies, fresh canned goods, etc. She is looking to become a wholesale distributor so she can get better income to help her family. Her dream is to have a large, well stocked store. This way she could distribute wholesale.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cookies, soft drinks, caramels, canned goods

loans.name: Martha Lorena

texts.es:
La señora Martha Lorena Ruíz F. se dedica a su negocio de venta de chinelas que con mucho entusiasmo comercializa en su localidad siendo este un negocio del cual percibe las utilidades para mantener a sus dos hijos ya que es madre soltera y debe proporcionar la educación a uno de sus pequeños por estar en la edad escolar.

Ella ha venido a Ceprodel para solicitar un crédito para la compra de las chinelas ya que requiere de estas para ofertarlas y así brindar las condiciones necesarias en su negocio y satisfacer a sus clientes. Espera muy confiadamente que su crédito será otorgado lo más pronto posible.
texts.en:
Martha Lorena Ruíz F. sells sandals. She sells from her location with great enthusiasm, as it is through this business that she receives the profits to take care of her two children. She is a single mother, and she needs to educate one of her little ones because he is school-aged. She has come to Ceprodel to ask for a loan to buy sandals to sell. She wants to offer the necessary business conditions to satisfy her customers. She very trustingly hopes that the loan will be granted as soon as possible.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy sandals

loans.name: Maria Asuncion

texts.es: María Asunción P. V. tiene la edad de 30 años, María es madre soltera. María tiene 5 hijos y todos asisten a escuela. La actividad económica es la elaboración y venta de pan. Hace más de 3 años que se dedica este negocio. Doña María inicia este negocio por su familia ya fueron sus padres se hacían cargo del negocio y debido a que sus padres no tenían el suficiente capital de trabajo es por eso que deciden que su Hija María se hiciera cargo de la panadería. Los propósitos de María es mantener el mejor record crediticio con Fundación León 2000 ya que ellos le brindaron la ayuda necesaria para salir adelante. El financiamiento es destinado para capital de trabajo para la compra de harina, azúcar, mantequilla, huevo y levadura. sus sueños son de que su panadería logre tener el mejor prestigio en la calidad de sus productos.
texts.en:
María Asunción P. V., 30, is a single mother. María has five children, and they all go to school. For more than three years she has been making and selling bread. She started the business for her family. Her parents were in charge of the business. However, they did not have sufficient working capital, so they decided that their daughter, María, would take over the bakery. Maria intents to maintain the best credit record with Fundación León 2000. They offered her the necessary help to get ahead. The loan is for working capital to buy flour, sugar, butter, eggs, and leavening. Her dream is that the bakery achieves the best prestige for the quality of its products.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Modesta

texts.es:
La señora Modesta, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mi Sueño”, vive en el Jr. A.A.H.H. Tupac Amarú Mayor Fap, Distrito de Juanjui, Provincia Mariscal Cáceres, Departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 64 años, 04 hijos todos ellos ya independientes y formando sus propias  familias.

Modesta, a su edad aun se siente con fuerzas para seguir trabajando, ella se dedica a la venta de bebidas gasificadas. Manifiesta que con el negocio que ejerce se siente muy tranquila y contenta, vive sola y es ella quien administra su negocio. También se dedica al alquiler de cuartos, donde recibe mensualmente los pagos por ellos adicionando a estos las ganancias por las  ventas de sus bebidas, se siente muy capaz y responsable con las cuotas que debe pagar mensualmente al Banco Comunal.

Actualmente continúa con el mismo negocio,  es conocida en el barrio; ya que sus gaseosas las vende bien heladitas al gusto del cliente.
Con este préstamo de S/ 1,000.00, desea invertirlo comprando mas bebidas gaseosas de diferentes sabores, tamaños y marcas. Así como agua mineral con gas y sin gas.
 
Modesta, se siente orgullosa por haber logrado implementar su negocio, y asegurarse una vejez tranquila. Agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por haberla ayudado a superarse y a otras mujeres que quieren salir adelante y a defenderse como mujeres.
texts.en:
Modesta belongs to the Mi Sueño Community Bank. She lives at Jr. A.A.H.H. Tupac Amarú Mayor Fap, Juanjui district, Mariscal Cáceres province, San Martín department. She is 64, married, and has four children. All of them are independent and have their own families. At her age, Modesta still feels strong enough to keep working. She sells soft drinks. She feels very calm and happy about the business she does. She lives alone, and she runs the business. She also rents out rooms for which she receives monthly payments. Those payments, plus the earnings from her soft drink sales, make her feel very capable and responsible about the monthly payments she needs to make to her Community Bank. She continues with the same business. She is known in her neighborhood since she sells the soft drinks nice and cold just as her customers like. With this loan for 1,000 PEN she would like to buy more soft drinks in different flavors, sizes, and brands. She would also buy carbonated and non carbonated mineral water. Modesta feels proud of herself for having been able to implement her business and assure herself of a peaceful old age. She is grateful to the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for having helped her improve herself. They have helped her and other women who want to get ahead and take care of themselves as women.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy soft drinks to increase her drinks

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es:
La señora Mercedes, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Virgen de las Mercedes”, vive en Jr. Eduardo Peña Nº 1238, Distrito de Juanjui, Provincia San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 24 años, tiene 01 hijo muy pequeño en etapa escolar.

Con el fin de contribuir con los ingresos económicos de su hogar, siendo muy joven y con ganas de trabajar le nace la idea de implementar un pequeño negocio con la venta de salchipapa ubicado en la esquina de su casa, con su primer prestamo en Manuela Ramos de S/. 300.00 y con el apoyo de su pareja compraron su primera herramienta de trabajo que fue su carrito salchipapero y luego; poco a poco fue comprando sus utensilios y materiales para brindar un mejor servicio a sus clientes.  

Hasta el día de hoy, sigue con la venta de salchipapa y comidas, nos cuenta que le va muy en sus ventas, lo ejerce en las noches, ya que a esa hora hay más movimiento, es ella misma quien atiende a sus clientes, con la amabilidad y carisma que le caracteriza. 

Con este préstamo de S/ 1,500.00, desea invertirlo comprando kilos de arroz y azucar, pollos en javas, sacos de papas (05) y algunos utensilios de cocina, para reemplazar a los que tiene actualmente y así brindar un mejor servicio y atención a sus clientes. 

Mercedes, se siente muy segura y con ganas de seguir adelante y asegurarse una  vida tranquila y  agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir  con el cumplimiento de sus sueños y metas.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mercedes belongs to the Community Bank 'Virgen of the Mercies', is 24 years old, and has one very young school age son. She lives with her partner at 1238 Jr. Eduardo Peña North, District of Juanjui, San Martín Province, Departament of San Martín. With the goal of contributing to the income of the household, being very young and with the desire to work, she had the idea of starting a small business with the sale of salchipapa (sausage) from a location in the corner of her house. With her first loan from Manuela Ramos of S/. 300.00 and with the help of her partner they bought her first equipment for the business which was a sausage cart and then, little by little, they continued buying utensils and materials to provide better service to her clients. Until today she continues with the sale of salchipapa and meals. She tells us that her sales are going very well. She works in the evenings since at this hour there is more activity. She herself attends her clients with her characteristic friendliness and charisma. With this loan of S/. 1,500.00 she wants to invest in buying pounds of rice and sugar, wholesale chicken, five sacks of potatoes, and some kitchen utensils to replace those that she now has, and provide better service and attention to her clients. Mercedes feels very confident and desires to continue moving ahead to assure herself a tranquil life and she thanks the Manuela Ramos Movement for contributing to the realization of her dreams and goal.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy supplies for preparing her meals

loans.name: Shirley

texts.es:
La señora Shirley, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Micaela Bastidas”, vive en el Jr. Mariscal Castilla Nº 282, Distrito de Juanjui, Provincia Mariscal Cáceres, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 37 años y 01 hijo, que aun dependen de ella.

Shirley, con el apoyo de su pareja y de Manuela Ramos y tendiendo  habilidad para la costura, decidió implementar su propio negocio ubicado en su misma casa,  se rige mas al rubro de confección de ropas de deporte. Nos cuenta que le va muy en sus ventas, trabaja con pedidos y los vende en docenas.
En la actualidad continua con sus confecciones de ropas de deporte y tiene una clientela ya fidelizada que a diario acude a su casa para realizar sus trabajos y pedidos, es ella quien personalmente les atiende  con la amabilidad que le caracteriza. 

Con el préstamo de S/ 1,000.00, desea invertirlo comprando telas en metros, de diferentes especies, instrumentos que utiliza como tijeras, agujas de coser y de maquina, alfileres, botones. 

Shirley, hoy en día se siente una mujer muy realizada, con más ganas de alcanzar y hacer realidad sus demás sueños. Agradece a Manuela Ramos por ayudarla a iniciar su negocio y también a muchas mujeres que  quieren crecer empresarialmente.
texts.en:
Señora Shirley, a customer of the Community Bank “Micaela Bastidas”, lives in Jr. Mariscal Castilla Nº 282, in the Juanjui district, Mariscal Cáceres Province of San Martín. She is 37 years old, and lives with her son and his father, who depend on her.

Shirley, with the support of her partner and of Manuela Ramos, and having sewing skills, decided to start her own business out of her house. She works mostly in the area of sportswear. She tells us that these sell well. She takes orders and sells by the dozen. Currently she is working on the manufacture of sports clothing, and she has a loyal customer base. She stays home each day completing her sewing and filling orders. She tends to her customers with the amiability that characterizes her.

With a loan of S/ 1,000.00, she will invest in fabric by the meter, of different styles, and tools like scissors, sewing needles for both machine and hand sewing, pins and buttons.

Shirley currently feels that she is an accomplished woman, with the desire to achieve and make her dreams a reality. She thanks Manuela Ramos for helping her start her business, as well as assisting many women who hope to expand their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fabric to make clothing

loans.name: Rosa Aurora

texts.es:
La señora Rosa Aurora, pertenece al Banco Comunal “El Abiseo”, vive en el Jr. Nicolás de Pierola  cdra. 05 –, Distrito de Juanjui, Departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 66 años y es madre de 09, tres de ellos que aun dependen de ella.

Ante la necesidad de aportar al ingreso económico del hogar, motivada por ella misma emprendió un pequeño  negocio de venta de abarrotes con su primer crédito de S/. 300.00 obteniendo muy buenos resultados desde un inicio por la calidad de sus productos, sus precios cómodos y la buena atención al cliente.
En la actualidad continua con el mismo negocio ubicada en su propia casa, con un local muy acondicionado, donde sus principales clientes son los vecinos de su barrio.

Con este préstamo de S/. 3,000.00, comprará  más productos para surtir su negocio como arroz y azúcar en kilos, huevos en javas,  insumos para el aseo personal y limpieza del hogar, gaseosas en paquetes, golosinas  y otros productos para mantener contenta a su clientela.

Hoy se siente muy feliz del trabajo que hace y agradece a Manuela Ramos, por apoyar a personas como ella que quieren trabajar y salir adelante, espera que sigan así por mucho tiempo y ayuden a muchas familias y mujeres emprendedoras.
texts.en:
Señora Rosa Aurora, a customer of the Community Bank “El Abiseo”, lives in Jr. Nicolás de Pierola cdra. 05 –,in the Juanjui district of San Martín. She is single, 66 years old, and has 9 children, three of whom still depend on her. Faced with the necessity to provide an income for her home, the self motivated Rosa started a small business selling groceries with her first loan of S/. 300.00. She was successful from the start due to the quality of her products, her reasonable prices and fine customer service. Currently, she operates the business out of her home, with a site in good condition, where her main customers are the people in her neighborhood. With this loan of S/. 3,000.00, Rosa will purchase more inventory to stock her business, such as rice and sugar by the kilo, eggs in bulk, personal hygiene and cleaning products, soft drinks by the case, sweets and other products to please her customers. Rosa is very happy with the work she has and thanks Manuela Ramos, for helping people like her who want to work and get ahead. She hopes Manuela continues her work for a long time and helps many families and women entrepreneurs.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in inventory to stock her grocery store

loans.name: Reyna

texts.es:
La señora Reyna C. J. se dedica con mucho esfuerzo a su negocio de venta de abarrotes en la ciudad de Managua atendiendo con mucha alegría a sus clientes y ofreciendo los granos básicos como lo son arroz, azúcar y frijoles y otros productos comestibles.

 Ella atraviesa la necesidad de invertir en su negocio y para ello ha acudido a Ceprodel para ser beneficiada con un crédito para dar lugar a la compra de los comestibles y de esta forma salir adelante en el negocio  y satisfacer a sus clientes que a diario le visitan en su localidad.
texts.en:
Señora Reyna C. J. devotes herself with much effort to her grocery business in the city of Managua. She assists her customers with much joy, and offers staples like rice, sugar, beans and other food products.

Reyna understands the need to invest in her business, so she went to Ceprodel to request a loan to help her purchase inventory in order to increase her business, and to satisfy the customers who patronize her shop every day.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase staple food products

loans.name: Antonia

texts.es: Antonia tiene 58 años, vive con su esposo y su último hijo de 14 años en su casa propia.	Edad, estado civil, miembros de su familia. Desde hace 5 años tuvo la idea de comprar carbón por camionadas y venderlo, desde entonces abastece cada semana a sus principales compradores que son las pequeñas fábricas de ladrillo que abundan por su localidad, ya que les sirve como combustible de sus hornos de condensación. En época de lluvia baja la demanda, por lo que es importante tener un almacén, este negocio le ha dado buenos resultados, y constantemente compra carbón de piedra y lo almacena en el patio de su casa. Para más adelante, Antonia desea seguir trabajando en esta actividad pero comprando mayores cantidades. Es la primera vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP, y su deseo es trabajar de manera armoniosa con sus compañeros de grupo. Este crédito será de mucha utilidad para Antonia, pues planea comprar una camionada de carbón de piedra para abastecerse.
texts.en:
Antonia is 58 years old and lives with her husband and youngest child, who is 14 years old. They live in their own home. Five years ago she had the idea of buying a truck load of coal and selling it. Ever since, she stocks her main buyers on a weekly basis. Her buyers are the many small factories that make bricks in her area. They use it for fuel in their condensation ovens. During the rainy season, there is not as much demand, which is why it’s important to have a warehouse. This business has been good so she is constantly buying stone coal and storing it on her home's patio. In the future, Antonia would like to continue working in this field, but she would like to buy in bigger quantities. This is her first loan with MFP, and she would like to work harmoniously with the other members of the group. The loan will be very useful to Antonia as she is planning to buy a load of stone coal to stock up.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Incremento de mercadería

loans.name: Mirtalia De Los Ángeles

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Managua, la señora Mirtalia M. O. se dedica a atender su negocio de venta de ropa el cual posee desde hace18 años siendo una excelente trabajadora en su ramo.

Es de importancia destacar que tiene muchos deseos de salir adelante en su negocio y para ello ha acudido a Ceprodel con el fin de solicitar un crédito para la compra de la ropa y de esta manera mejorar su condición en el negocio.
texts.en:
Ms. Mirtalia M. O. runs her own business in the city of Managua. She sells clothes and has been in the business for 18 years. She has been doing an excellent job in this field.

It is important to highlight that she strives to keep her business going. She has requested a loan to Ceprodel for the purchase of clothing and the improvement of her business.

Translated from Spanish by Adriana Pierce, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of clothing for her business

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es: Carmen tiene 36 años, vive con su esposo y sus 3 hijos de 18, 16 y 12 años, en su casa propia. Hace 3 años, junto a su esposo, se mudaron a su actual casa, donde surgió la idea de tener un negocio propio que le permita generarse más ingresos y ser parte sustentadora de su hogar, entonces empezó a vender balones de gas, alfalfa y la leche que produce su vaca. Su diario trabajo consiste en levantarse muy temprano para extraer la alfalfa de sus tierras de cultivo, ordeñar a su vaca y abrir su pequeño establecimiento donde realiza sus ventas en su misma casa, y cuando es necesario sus hijos la ayudan a llevar los pedidos a las casa de sus vecinos. Para mejorar su negocio, Carmen quiere arreglar la infraestructura de su casa para seguir dedicándose a la venta de los balones de gas y la alfalfa, pero en un espacio con mayor comodidad. Es la primera vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP, y es nueva en esta experiencia del trabajo solidario con su banco comunal, por lo que tiene amplias expectativas, y sabe que será parte importante para promover la unidad en su grupo. El dinero que solicita lo va a utilizar en la compra de más balones de gas en otras marcas y tener mayor variedad en su mercadería.
texts.en:
Carmen is 36 years old, lives in her own house with her husband and 3 children who are 18, 16 and 12 years old. She and her husband moved 3 years ago to their current home where she got the idea of starting her own business, one that allowed her to generate more revenue and support her family. She started selling propane gas tanks, alfalfa and milk . Her daily job is to get up very early to pick the alfalfa harvest, milk her cow and open her small store where she sells her products. Her children help delivering orders to neighbors when it is needed.

Carmen wants to fix the infrastructure of her house to improve her business and continue engaging in the sale of gas tanks and alfalfa in a more comfortable area. This is the first time she has a loan with MFP, and is new to the experience of working with her community bank. She has big expectations and knows that she will play an important role to promote unity in her group. The money requested will be used in the purchase of gas tanks in different brands and a greater variety of merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Adriana Pierce, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose A. is a 31-year-old mother of seven children. She is married, but is the sole bread-winner for the family right now. She lives in Nyalenda slum here in Kisumu. She runs a vegetable kiosk that is located next to a beauty salon (pronounced saloon in Kenya). The challenges she faces are fluctuations in the purchasing power of her customers. She hopes to use half the loan for personal use (we were told off camera: school fees) and the other half for increasing her food stocks for her kiosk. She asked that K-MET increase the amount of business training that they give borrowers.

In this video, you can hear me greet Rose saying "Idhi Nade" -- which is Luo for "How are you?" Rose responds, "Adhi maber," meaning "very good." Most people living in Kisumu descend from the Luo tribe, the same tribe as Obama's father. At the end, you will hear me fluctuate between Kiswahili and Luo saying "Asante Sana" in Kiswahili, meaning "Thank you" and Erokamano, which in Luo, means "thank you." The voices you hear in the background are coming for a weekly K-MET borrower meeting. To see what one looks like, check out the first video in this blog post: http://fellowsblog.kiva.org/2009/05/14/m-banking/

loans.use: Vegetables, Fruits for resale

loans.name: Hermelinda

texts.es: Hermelida tiene 39 años, vive con su hijo de 12 en su casa propia. Su trabajo diario consiste en la atención de la tienda que instaló en su misma casa, vende comestibles de primera necesidad, como abarrotes, verduras, frutas, gaseosas, entre otros. Su dedicación y vocación al trabajo los mantiene a lo largo de 8 años de llevar este negocio, y en algunas ocasiones, sobre todo los fines de semana sale a vender comida en las fiestas costumbristas de su localidad. Debido a su perseverancia y calidez de su trabajo, Hermelinda a crecido progresivamente, por ello tiene planes para el futuro de mejorar la infraestructura de su  tienda para que sea más atractiva y al gusto de sus clientes. Es la primera vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP, y su disposición para trabajar en unión con su banco comunal es muy grande. El dinero que solicita será invertido en la compra de sacos de menestras para implementar su tienda.
texts.en:
Hermelida is 39 years old, and lives with her 12 year-old son in her own home. Her daily work consists of looking after her shop, which she has set up in her own home. She sells food items like groceries, vegetables, fruits, soft drinks, and other items. She has maintained a dedication and calling to her work for 8 years. Sometimes, above all during the weekends, she goes out to sell food in the traditional fiestas in her area.

Thanks to her perseverance and the quality of her work, Hermelinda has grown her business progressively. She has plans for the future to improve the infrastructure of her store so that it might be more attractive to her clients.

This is the first time she has sought a loan with MFP, and she has great hopes to work in union with her bank. The loan she seeks will be invested in the purchase of sacks of vegetable stew to supplement her inventory.

Translated from Spanish by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her merchandise

loans.name: Hilda

texts.es: Hilda tiene 43 años, vive en su casa propia con su esposo y sus 2 hijos. Desde hace 4 años, su tarea principal, muy temprano por las mañanas, es la limpieza de su granja y alimentación de sus animales, cría pollos y cuyes, lo cuales vende todos los fines de semana desde su casa, y en algunas ocasiones en la feria ganadera de su localidad. Con la experiencia adquirida, Hilda sabe que en los primeros meses del año las ventas decrecen y los demás meses hay mayor demanda, esto le genera las ganancias que necesita para su hogar, por ello, desea incrementar su capital para aprovechar la buena temporada que se acerca para su negocio. Es la primera vez tiene un préstamo con MFP, y su primera experiencia en un banco comunal, para ella es un gran reto, porque ha escuchado que el trabajo solidario se expresa con el trabajo en equipo. El dinero que solicita es para comprar más pollos y cuyes para abastecer a sus clientes durante los próximos meses.
texts.en:
Hilda is 43 years old, and lives in her own home with her husband and two children. For the last four years, her main task, very early in the morning, is to clean her farm and feed her animals. She raises chickens and guinea pigs, which she sells on the weekends from her home. Sometimes she sells at livestock markets near her home. With the experience she has acquired, Hilda knows that in the first months of the year, sales decrease, and in later months there is greater demand. This is when she generates the income she needs for her home. Therefore, she would like to supplement her capital to take advantage of the busy season that is approaching for her business. This is Hilda's first loan with MFP, and her first experience with a community bank. For Hilda, it is a challenge, because she has heard that solitary work is expressed in the work of the group. The money she is requesting is to buy more chickens and guinea pigs to fatten for her customers during the coming months.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase chickens and guinea pigs

loans.name: Inés

texts.es: Inés tiene 33 años, vive con su pequeño hijo y su esposo en casa de su madre. Su deseo de emprender un negocio independiente, y de ayudar en la economía de su hogar la motivó a invertir sus ahorros en la compra de balones de gas, lo cuales vende en la tienda de abarrotes de su madre todos los días, incluyendo los fines de semana. Ya son 3 meses desde que empezó su negocio y ha empezado a ver resultados muy positivos, debido a que sus vecinos siempre le hacen pedidos de balones de gas, ya que es el combustible para sus cocinas y la preparación diaria de los alimentos. Para más adelante, Inés está viendo la posibilidad de abrir un local exclusivo de venta de balones de gas. Es la primera vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP, el banco comunal que integra también es nuevo, y ella fue una de las que impulsó su formación con grandes expectativas de crecimiento. El dinero que solicita será para comprar mayor cantidad de balones de gas.
texts.en:
Inés, 33, lives with her small son and her husband in her mother’s house. Her desire to undertake an independent business and to help with the family expenses motivated her to invest her savings in the purchase of gas tanks. She sells the gas tanks everyday, including week ends, in her mother’s grocery store. It has now been three months since she started her business, and she has started to see very positive results. This is due to the fact that her neighbors always order tanks of gas from her because that is what they use in their kitchens and in their daily food preparation. In the future, Inés is looking at the possibility of opening a stand that sells gas tanks exclusively. This is her first loan with MFP. Her community bank is also new, and she was one of the members that started the group with great expectations of growth. The loan is to buy a larger quantity of gas tanks.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Armando Javier

texts.es:
A sus 41 años de edad, en la ciudad de Masaya, el señor Armando Z. se dedica a su actividad de elaboración de hamacas típicas dedicándose a esto desde hace 7 años habiendo alcanzado una gran experiencia en este trabajo.

Actualmente, el señor Armando requiere de la compra de los materiales de trabajo para elaborar las hamacas ya que son comercializadas tanto a personas nacionales como a extranjeros. Es por este motivo que él ha acudido a Ceprodel para solicitar un crédito para la compra de dichos materiales de trabajo con el fin de continuar elaborando estas bellísimas hamacas típicas Nicaragüenses para todas las personas.
texts.en:
At 41 years of age, in the city of Masaya, Armando Z. makes typical hammocks. He has been doing this for seven years, and he has achieved a high level of experience in this work. Currently, Armand needs to buy work materials to make his hammocks, which are commercialized as much to Nicaraguans as to foreigners. For this reason he has come to Ceprodel to ask for a loan. He will use the loan to buy work materials to continue making this beautiful, typical, Nicaraguan hammocks for everyone.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy work materials

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.es: Ruth es casada, vive con su esposo en casa de sus padres. Se dedica a la venta de verduras por las mañanas hasta el medio día en un pequeño mercado de su localidad, y por las tardes cuida de su granja de cerdos para que estén en buen estado y adecuadamente alimentados para venderlos a un precio que le otorgue buenas ganancias. Ruth también está empezando a dedicarse a la crianza de vacas, ya que la venta de animales es un negocio rentable, por ello ha planificado para el futuro tener un establo más grande, donde pueda criar a mayor cantidad de animales. Este es su primer préstamo con MFP, y el dinero que solicita será invertido en la compra de alimento para sus cerdos y verduras al por mayor.
texts.en:
Ruth is married; she and her husband live in her parents’ house. She sells vegetables in the mornings until the middle of the day. She sells in a small market in her area. In the afternoons she takes care of her pig farm. She makes sure that they are in good shape and adequately fed so that she can sell them for a good price that will give her good earnings. Ruth is also starting to raise cattle because selling animals is a profitable business. In the future she plans to have a bigger stable where she can raise a larger quantity of animals. This is her first loan with MFP. The money is to buy food for the pigs and to buy wholesale vegetables.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy food for her pigs

loans.name: Soledad

texts.es: Soledad tiene 32 años, vive con su esposo y su pequeña hija de 3 años en casa de sus suegros. Debido a la demanda por el uso del Internet, hace 2 años decidió implementar un negocio de servicio de cabinas públicas para el uso de Internet, para ello acondicionó un espacio que le cedieron sus suegros en su casa. Soledad atiende todos los días para poder generar los ingresos necesarios para su hogar, alquilando sus computadoras por horas. Su negocio hasta el momento ha dado buenos frutos, por ser la única con este servicio en su localidad, eso la ánima a progresar y mejorar sus maquinas para ofrecer un mejor y más rápido servicio. Este es su primer préstamo con MFP, y su primera experiencia en un banco comunal, sin embargo Soledad tiene muchos deseos de emprender un trabajo solidario con todos sus compañeros. El dinero que está solicitando es para comprar memorias para sus computadoras y repotenciar la capacidad de almacenaje de información que poseen.
texts.en:
Soledad is 32 years old and lives with her husband and small 3-year old daughter in her in-laws’ house. Because of the demand for Internet access, she decided 2 years ago to start a business providing public Internet booths. For this, she outfitted some space that her in-laws provided inside their home. Soledad tends to her business each and every day in order to generate the necessary income for the household, renting her computers out on an hourly basis. Her business has been fruitful so far, as it is the only such service in her area. This motivates her to continue to progress and upgrade her machines so she can offer a better and faster service. This is her first loan with MFP, and her first experience in a cooperative bank. Regardless, Soledad has a great desire to work in a team environment with all of her colleagues. The funds she is requesting are for buying memory for her computers, to expand the amount of information they can store.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase the memory on her computers.

loans.name: Marvin Fransisco

texts.es: Marvin Francisco C. Arteaga tiene la edad de 45 años. Don Marvin tiene un taller de carpintería. Hace más de 15 años que se dedica a este negocio. Y dio inicio a este con muy pocas herramientas como una cierra, martillo y un cepillo. Actualmente tiene a trabajadores en su taller. Marvin solicita el este crédito para la compra de una sierra circular, con todos los dispositivos de seguridad, lo cual le permitirá agilizar la realización y entrega de sus productos de madera. Marvin realiza sus trabajos por encargo. Marvin tiene los propósitos de salir adelante con este negocio, ya que le ayudo a salir adelante con su vida. Los deseos de Marvin son que sus hijos coronen una carrera profesional y que sus hijos tengan las oportunidades que el no pudo tener.
texts.en:
Marvin Francisco C. Arteaga is 45 years old and has a carpentry workshop. He has dedicated himself to this type of work for more than 15 years, which he started with just a few tools such as a saw, a hammer and a plane. He currently has workers in his workshop. Marvin requests this loan to buy a circular saw, with all the safety features, that would allow him to finish and deliver his wood products faster. Each of Marvin’s pieces is made to order. Marvin aspires to get ahead with this business, given that it has helped him improve his quality of life. His wishes are that his children become career professionals and have opportunities that he was not able to have.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Teodora

texts.es: Teodora tiene 36 años, vive con su esposo y sus 2 hijas de 20 y 15 años en su casa propia. Ser ama de casa, no es limitación, por lo que ha decidido abrir en su propia casa una tienda, la cual le permita atender su hogar y a la vez generar ingresos económicos. La buena atención que ofrece cada día y el peso exacto de cada producto, han logrado que en sólo 2 años, su bodega crezca rápidamente y sus clientes estén en aumento. El horario de mayor venta durante el día es cuando se acerca el medio día, ella es la única encargada de la atención de su tienda y aunque refiere que es un trabajo cansado, también es gratificante porque diariamente está en contacto con sus clientes. Para más adelante, Teodora piensa tener una tienda más grande donde pueda ofrecer mayor variedad de productos comestibles. Este es su primer préstamo con MFP, y está muy entusiasmada de pertenecer a su nuevo banco comunal, donde promete ser una integrante activa y responsable. El dinero que está solicitando será invertido en la compra de mercadería; un saco de arroz valorizado en 60 soles, y con el resto comprará arena para mejorar la infraestructura de su casa, y a su vez de su tienda.
texts.en:
Teodora is 36 years old and lives with her husband and 2 children, ages 20 and 15, in their own house. To be a housewife is no limitation, for she has decided to open a store in her own home, which will enable her to both take care of her home and generate income. The good attention that she offers every day, and the exact weight of every product, means that she has succeeded in only 2 years; her store grows rapidly and her clients are increasing. The best time of the day for sales is near mid-day; Teodora is the only attendant in the store, and although that means tiring work, it is also gratifying because she has daily contact with her clients. To advance, Teodora is thinking of having a bigger store where she could offer a larger variety of edible products. This is her first loan with MFP, and she is very enthusiastic to belong to a new communal bank, where she promises to be an active and responsible member. The money she is requesting will be invested in the purchase of merchandise; a sack of rice worth 60 soles, and the rest will buy sand to improve the infrastructure of her house, and, in turn, her store.

Translated from Spanish by Cara Gutterman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her merchandise

loans.name: Agustín

texts.es: Agustín tiene 34 años, vive en una casa arrendada. Hace 5 años decidió invertir sus ahorros en la compra de ropa y otros accesorios personales, los cuales vende en un puesto del mercado de su localidad todos los días. Agustín le pone mucho empeño a su negocio, ya que la responsabilidad y la perseverancia son actitudes que practica desde muy joven. Para el futuro, Agustín quiere alquilar otro puesto de ventas para incrementar la cantidad de artículos que vende, y con ello aumentar sus ganancias. Este e su primer préstamo con MFP, y también es una experiencia nueva ser parte de un banco comunal, donde está seguro que aprenderá mucho y mejorará sus relaciones interpersonales. Con el dinero que solicita comprará más mercadería para implementar su puesto.
texts.en:
Agustín is 34 years old and lives in a rented house. Five years ago, he decided to invest his savings in purchasing clothing and other personal accessories, which he sells every day at a stand in his town market. Agustín puts a lot of effort into his business, given that responsibility and perseverance are traits he has practiced since he was young. In the future, Agustín would like to rent another stand to increase the quantity of articles that he sells, and in this way, increase his earnings. This is his first loan with MFP, and it is also a new experience for him to be part of a community bank, where he is sure he will learn a lot and improve his interpersonal relationships. With this money that he is asking for, Agustín will buy more merchandise to start his stand.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more merchandise

loans.name: Darling Aracely

texts.es: Darling Aracely Rodríguez Martínez tiene la edad de 26 años, su estado civil es soltera. Darling tiene 1 hijo y asiste a una escuela. La actividad económica es la venta de mercadería en general. Hace más de 8 años que se dedica a este negocio. Darling es una joven muy trabajadora y siempre le ha gustado trabajar, ya que tenia que hacerse cargo de su hijo, es por eso que decidió ingresar al mercado con este negocio. Los propósitos de Darling son que su clientela aumente para que tener una variedad de gustos. El dinero solicitado es para capital de trabajo en la compra de cosméticos, calzado, ropa interior entre otros. Los sueños de esta Joven son de seguir trabajando con fundación león 2000 ya que es por medio de ella que recibe la ayuda de las organizaciones amigas.
texts.en:
Darling Aracely Rodríguez Martínez is 26 years old and is single. Darling has a son and attends school. She makes money in general by selling merchandise. She has dedicated herself to this business for more than 8 years. Darling is a hardworking young woman, and she has always liked to work, since she has had to take care of her son. It is for this reason that she decided to enter the market with this business. Darling's goals are to expand her clientele so that she will have a variety of tastes. The money that she is requesting is for working capital to buy cosmetics, footwear, underwear, etc. This young woman's dreams are to continue working with Fundación León 2000 since it is through it that she receives the help of the partner organizations.

Translated from Spanish by Anne R., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cosmetics, footwear, underwear, etc.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Abel Eliseo

texts.es: El joven  Abel Eliseo es originario de la comunidad de Nimasac del departamento de Totonicapan el visita las oficinas de ASDIR de un credito la cual  seran invertidos para gastos de estudios ya que esta finalizando sus estudios universitarios, el joven dia a  dia se esta actualizando para prepararce en fututo, asi poder  tener mayor oportunidad de trabajo hoy esta trabajando como asesor de creditos de una empresa de Totonicapan.
texts.en:
Abel Eliseo, a young man, is from the community of Nimasac in the department of Totonicapan. He visited the offices of ASDIR about a loan which will be invested in education expenses, now that he is finishing his university studies. The young man is working every day to prepare himself for the future so that he may have greater opportunity for work such as a credit advisor for a business in Totonicapan.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Education expenses

loans.name: Domitila

texts.en:
Domitila is a member of the Virgen de Los Angeles Village Bank, which meets once per month in the town of Huayllacocha, about an hour from the city of Cusco. She is 51 years old and married with seven children, four of whom are adults living independently in Lima and Cusco, while three are children who still live at home. Domitila owns a small farm with her husband and also has a business buying and selling local products such as barley, broad beans and corn. She buys the crops from her neighbors and resells them in the jungle city of Quillabamba, about five hours away, travelling there about once per month.

Domitila is requesting a loan of 2000 soles to buy wheat, broad beans and corn, pledging to repay this loan on time and in full. She is grateful for the loans offered to her by Asociacion Arariwa since it is the only institution providing financial services in her town.

loans.use: To buy wheat, broad beans and corn.

loans.name: Maruja

texts.en:
Maruja is a member of the Virgen de Los Angeles Village Bank, which meets once per month in the town of Huayllacocha, about an hour from the city of Cusco. She is also the group’s secretary, meaning that she is responsible for taking the minutes at each meeting and recording payments.

Maruja is 31 years old and married with two school-aged children. She buys barley, corn and broad beans (“habas”) from local farmers, then brings these products to the markets in the cities of Urubamba and Cusco to resell. She has been in this line of work for the past ten years. She usually works alone, though her husband helps sometimes. The couple also has a small farm of their own, where they have five pigs and two cows in addition to farming crops.

Maruja is requesting a loan of 1000 soles to buy more barley, corn and broad beans. She has been a client of Asociación Arariwa for several years now. She has been a member of the Virgen de Los Angeles group for two years, and prior to then she worked with another Arariwa bank. She is grateful for the loans offered by Arariwa, since it is the only institution that offers financial services in her community.

Maruja has pledged to repay her Kiva loan in full and on time. Her goal for the future is for both of her children to graduate from college.

loans.use: To buy barley, corn, and beans for resale

loans.name: Julia Marleni

texts.en:
Marleni is a member of the Virgen de los Angeles Village Bank, which meets once a month in the town of Huayllacocha, about an hour from the city of Cusco. Asociacion Arariwa is the only institution offering loans in this town. Marleni is 30 years old, single, and lives with her parents and siblings. Marleni’s family has a farm in Huayllacocha, where she works with her siblings. Marleni also has her own business buying and selling locally grown barley and bean flour; she buys from her neighbours and travels to Cusco and Quillabamba to resell the products. She usually travels two or three times per month, depending on how much she is needed on the farm. Marleni also has a few farm animals of her own: five pigs, two cows, and a handful of guinea pigs (a Peruvian delicacy).

Marleni is requesting a loan of 2000 soles to buy local crops. She plans to buy about ten sacks of broad beans (“habas”), eight or nine sacks of corn, and twenty sacks of barley. Her goal for the future is to buy more animals so that she can start her own small farm; she would like to buy chickens, more pigs and more guinea pigs.

loans.use: To buy beans, corn, and barley for resale

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en:
Paulina is a member of the Virgen de los Angeles Village Bank, which meets once per month in the town of Huayllacocha, where she lives. Paulina is forty-seven years old and married with six children. Her children are all adults, and three of them still live at home with her. Paulina and her family have a farm where they grow potatoes, barley, wheat and broad beans (“habas”). She has been working on the farm for many years, and is now preparing for the upcoming barley harvest in June. She and her husband also raise a handful of cows and sheep. 

Paulina is requesting a loan to invest in livestock. She plans to buy either sheep or a cow; the money would be enough to buy one cow or five sheep, she says. She would raise the animals and eventually sell them for meat. 

Paulina has been a client of Asociacion Arariwa for the past six years, and is grateful for the loans available to her because it is the only institution that works in her town. She has pledged to repay her Kiva loan in full and on time.

loans.use: Buy sheep or a cow

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia is a member of the Virgen de los Angeles VIllage Bank, which meets once a month in the town of Huayllacocha, where she lives. Julia is thirty-seven years old and married with three children who are nine, seven and three years old. Julia and her husband have a farm where they grow barley, potatoes, wheat and broad beans (“habas”). The potato harvest just ended, and they will soon harvest barley in June. 

Julia is requesting a loan to buy piglets and lambs. She isn’t quite sure how many of each she will buy yet, but the money is enough to buy about four small pigs. She will fatten the animals up for several months and then sell them in the market in the town of Izcuchaca, the nearby transportation/commerce hub. For example, if she buys a pig for $65, Julia says, she will be able to sell the same pig two months later for $85. She has been working with livestock for many years now, she says, and has also been a member of Asociacion Arariwa for many years, though she can’t think of exactly how long it’s been. 

Julia has pledged to repay her Kiva loan in full and on time. Her goal is to be able to take out larger loans in the future. She is grateful for the loans offered by Asociacion Arariwa, since it is the only financial institution that offers services in her town.

loans.use: Buy piglets and lambs

loans.name: Sabina

texts.en:
Sabina is a member of the Virgen de los Angeles Village Bank, which meets each month in the town of Huayllacocha, where she lives. Sabina is forty-one years old and is married with four children. Three of her children are adults and live independently, while her youngest daughter is nine years old and lives with her. All three of her adult children are in college or have graduated from college: one studied education and teaches in Lima, another is studying accounting in Cusco, and her third child is currently living in Cuba and studying medicine. 

Sabina and her husband have a farm where they grow potatoes, barley, corn, peas and broad beans (“habas”). They also have two cows and twelve pigs on the farm. Sabina is requesting a loan which she will send to her son in Cuba to help pay for his educational and living expenses. She plans to repay the loan with the money she earns from selling her animals. 

Sabina’s goal for the future is for all four of her children to graduate from college; then she wants to rest. She has pledged to repay her Kiva loan in full and on time. Sabina is grateful for the loans offered by Asociacion Arariwa, since it is the only financial institution that offers services in her town.

loans.use: Pay for son's medical school

loans.name: Guillermina

texts.en:
Guillermina is a member of the Virgen D. Los Angeles VIllage Bank, which meets once a month in the town of Huayllacocha, where she lives. Her daughter, Zoila, is the group’s president and is also a Kiva client. Guillermina is seventy-eight years old and married with four children, fourteen grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren. Guillermina sells chicha, a traditional Andean corn beer, as well as vegetables at the market in Izcuchaca, the largest nearby town, which is located about thirty minutes away. She works seven days a week at the market, as does her daughter Zoila. Guillermina has been selling chicha for fifty or sixty years now, she says. 

Guillermina is requesting a loan, which she plans to use to buy corn for making chicha, as well as to buy a variety of locally grown foods like potatoes, broadbeans (“habas”), onions and barley. She usually buys thirty 14-kilo sacks of corn a week for making chicha; each sack generally costs about $7. 

Guillermina has been a member of her village bank for the past four years. She has pledged to repay her Kiva loan in full and on time. She is grateful for the loan being offered to her by Asociacion Arariwa, since it is the only financial institution that offers services in her town.

loans.use: Buy corn to make chicha, other vegetables

loans.name: Remedias

texts.en:
Remedias B. is a fashion dealer. She sells facial powder, shampoos, cologne, perfumes and other cosmetics products to earn a living for her family. She has only one child. Her husband, Maximo B. is a driver. With her husband's income from driving, she thinks they will not be able to buy their other needs. 

She would like to ask for a loan of Php 8,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fashion products for sale. She also considers looking for some other possible income areas to help her husband.

By joining in the CEVI credit program, she has ready access for credit to support her business. In addition to that, she also receives training and insurance coverage services.

loans.use: To buy fashion products for sale

loans.name: Zoila

texts.en:
Zoila is the president of the Virgen D. Los Angeles Village Bank, which meets once a month in the town of Huayllacocha, where she lives. Zoila is sixty years old and is the widowed mother of three children, all of whom are now adults with families of their own. Zoila’s main business is selling “jora,” the fermented corn used to make chicha, a traditional Andean corn beer. She buys dried corn in 14-kilo sacks for $7 apiece, soaks the corn to ferment it, and resells each 14-kilo sack for $10 soles to local chicha producers. She works seven days a week selling jora at the market in Izcuchaca, a large town about thirty minutes away that serves as a transportation and commerce hub for the Anta region. She usually works from 6:00 am to 3:00 or 4:00 pm, depending on business, and earns about $20 per day in profits. She has been in this line of work for the past ten years, and has developed rheumatism over the years from having her hands in cold jora water all throughout the day. 

Zoila is requesting a loan to buy sacks of dried corn. The money should be enough to buy 100 sacks of corn. Zoila has pledged to repay her Kiva loan in full and on time. She is grateful for the loans offered to her by Asociacion Arariwa, since it is the only financial institution that offers services in her town.

loans.use: Buy dried corn for fermentation

loans.name: Ligaya

texts.en:
"My husband often goes out fishing so that he will have plenty of fish that I could sell. We have a boat. Fishing is the only thing that supports our family. In God's mercy we were able to pay little by little our debts. I wish that we could add fishing boats so that we could be able to send our children to school," says Ligaya T., a 44-year old mother of eight children.

She would like to ask for a loan of Php 8,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy pangal, a fishing material that is efficient for a good catch. She also considers expanding her business even more.

CEVI is reaching out a lot Filipino community members to start and have their own businesses. CEVI gives not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To buy pangal, a  fishing material

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
" I dream that someday my sari-sari store business will turn to something bigger where I could display more goods and earn bigger sales of my products. My experience in selling somehow taught me how to deal with people and situations, especially when there are only few sales", says Gina B., 39-year old mother of five children. 

She would like to ask a loan of Php 10,000. The loan will be used in buying additional merchandise for her sari-sari store business. 

Through CEVI, Mrs. B. has ready access to credit to support her business. She also received leadership trainings and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To buy additional merchjandise for her sari-sari store business.

loans.name: Hang

texts.en: Hang S. H. is 65 years old and lives in the Province of Kampong Chhnang. She is a widowed mother who has given birth to four children, all of whom are married and also help her with business operations. She currently makes baskets in her home and she uses a bicycle to transport baskets to sell door-to-door around her community. She will use the loan to purchase additional raw materials in order to make baskets to sell.

loans.use: To purchase additional raw materials

loans.name: Ruben

texts.en:
"I started my business using my own capital. I want to make it grow and to be able to establish my own space for my business. The income that I get from duplicating and selling keys, locks and doorknobs is what I use to pay for the schooling of my four children," says Ruben M., 41-year-old entrepreneur from Trinindad Bohol.

He would like to ask for a loan of Php 5,000 from CEVI. He will use the loan to buy blank keys for replication in his key duplicator business. He also considers looking for some possible income areas to further help his family pay for all their needs.

Through CEVI, Mr. M. has ready-access-credit to support his business. He also receives training and insurance coverage services by joining in the CEVI credit program.

loans.use: To buy blank keys for replication in his key duplicator business

loans.name: Dante

texts.en:
Dante P. is from the town of Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 60 years old. Dante is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Dante owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling wood & wood-related products in the local community. Dante has been engaged in his business for over four years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In April 2009, Dante joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dante is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Dante from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Liezel

texts.en:
Liezel L. is from the town of Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 27 years old and married. To make a living, Liezel owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste to the local community. Liezel is just starting this business.

In 2008, Liezel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liezel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Liezel is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to purchase more products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Liezel from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Mrs. Elena M. is 42 years old and married with seven children: five of them are working and two are still in school. Her husband is a laborer with Soleman Industry. They are from Clarin, Misamis Occidental. 
To cope with financial insufficiency, she decided to open a sari-sari store in order to have finances specifically for their daily needs. She started with minimal capital of 3000 pesos only. A relative spoke to her about Paglaum MPC programs and services. She decided to become a full member in April, 2005, to be able to obtain a loan for additional capital. She dreams of expanding her business to a bigger concrete store and of sending her children through school. She hopes to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: Additional capital for a sari-sari store

loans.name: Rother

texts.en:
Rother F. is from the town of Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old and widowed with four school-aged children. To make a living, Rother makes and sells food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling dried goods in the local community. Rother has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Rother joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rother has successfully repaid a previous loan of 28000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Rother is requesting a new loan of 28000 PHP which will be used to again purchase raw ingredients. This loan will be the sixth taken out by Rother from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.
