*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Tun

texts.en:
Tun S., 66 years old, lives with her family in the province of Kompong Cham in Cambodia. She and her husband are crop growers and the older couple have given birth to eight children: three are single and five are married and have already started a new family. To provide a little more of the family's food needs, two of their single children are working as garment workers.

Tun S. can generate much income from her investment because she is widely known and has farmed since she was young. Tun S. is applying for a loan to purchase a small-sized plantation near her house in order to grow cane trees during the rainy season. (She and her husband are pictured).

loans.use: To purchase a small-sized plantation

loans.name: Sonia Elizabeth

texts.es: Sonia Elizabeth M. V. vive en Santa Tecla departamento La libertad, Sonia es madre soltera de 3 hijos que viven con ella, el ser madre soltera no es fácil para esta mujer es por ello que trabaja todo el día para que a sus hijos nunca les falte nada, esta madre ejemplar y muestra de lucha y trabajo, se dedica a la elaboración de pupusas y tortillas todos los días, también posee un pequeño inventario de venta de bebidas todo esto dentro de su misma casa, ahora Sonia solicita un crédito para poder adquirir más bebidas y así aumentar su inventario de productos que le ayudaran a obtener mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Sonia Elizabeth M. V. lives in Santa Tecla in the department of La Libertad. Sonia is a single mother of 3 children that live with her. Being a single mother is not easy for this woman. For this reason, she works all day so that her children never lack anything. This exemplary mother and model of fighting and working dedicates herself to making maize dumplings and tortillas every day. She also has a small inventory of drinks to sell inside of her own home. Now Sonia is asking for a loan to buy more drinks and in this way, expand her inventory of products that help her to obtain greater earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more drinks to expand her business

loans.name: Razia

texts.en:
Razia baji is a wife of M. A. and a citizen of a city named Kasur, Pakistan for the past 10 years. Kasur city is famous for its sweetmeat and for its shrines. They both are very hard workers. They own a decorative embroidery business.

Her husband goes to markets and gets orders from the clothing shops and then Razia baji and her daughter prepare the embroidered dresses and earn income. They both complete one dress in 10 days and earn Pak rupees 15,000 to 18,000. Razia baji is applying for a loan to buy material (colored thread, clothes, beads and sketches) to complete the order of shop keepers.

loans.use: To buy material to complete orders

loans.name: Blandina

texts.en: Blandina J. currently sells tea and is requesting a loan to open up a restaurant at the market of Gudele. She is a 30-year-old woman whose husband died two years ago. She has three children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she will pay school fees for her children. BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open a restaurant

loans.name: Sweetie Pie

texts.en:
Sweetie Pie began her retailing business two years ago. She decided to start this business because she knows it will help her in providing for the needs of her family.

She is seeking the support of Kiva Lenders for a loan of PHP 9,000 as additional working capital for her village store. She would like to improve her business by purchasing additional products and stocks of groceries to sell.

Sweetie Pie’s main goal in life is to be able to send her three children to school until they finish their studies in college. She knows that by having an education, they could easily uplift their family’s standard of living someday. She would be content in life just to see her children live a successful life someday.

Sweetie Pie is 42 years old and married to Nelson L. who is 46 years old and works at a local company. They have three children: Hersal is 21 years old and is a criminology graduate but has decided to take a care-giver course so he may move to London; Charmaine is 18 years old and she is presently studying in college taking a nursing course; their youngest is Denise who is 12 years old and is studying in secondary school.

loans.use: To purchase additional products and stocks of groceries to sell

loans.name: In

texts.en: The two people shown in the picture are Mrs. In H. and her husband. They live in Kompong Cham Province. In H. is the 47-year-old, married mother of three children, two of whom are married and living independently. In H.'s husband is a local primary school teacher. In H. currently cultivates rice and vegetable crops, and she will be using the loan money as capital to begin selling grocery items.

loans.use: To begin selling grocery items

loans.name: Asma

texts.en:
My name is Asma and I'm a citizen of a city named Kasur, Pakistan, where I have lived for the past 10 years. The city of Kasur is famous for its sweetmeats and for its shrines. I am an uneducated woman because my parents couldn't afford my education expenses.

My husband, M. I., runs a scrap business. He has three years of experience in this business. I help my husband by packing the scrap into sacks. I am applying for a loan to buy scrap for my husband's scrap business.

loans.use: To buy scrap for scrap business

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is married to an army officer, Arthur I., who is 43 years old. They live in Purok (district) Bannauag, Magsaysay, Naguilian, Isabela. They are blessed with one child, Angeline I., who is seven years old. Teresita is proud having a family that is happy and has a strong bond. She hopes that the good relationship in their family remains.

Teresita has been managing a sari-sari store (typical village store) in her village for about ten years. She has been running this store since long before she got married to her husband. Sometimes she has to close her business because her revolving capital has to be used for emergencies. Teresita wants to expand her business so that she does not have to close her store when an unexpected event happens. She is requesting a loan of PHP 9,000 from the lenders.

She believes that there is always a prize in every sacrifice; thus, she is working hard to acquire more prizes in the future. The loan she requested will help a great deal in expanding her business and her family’s life, Teresita added.

loans.use: To use as business capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is happily married to Danny T.. She is 45 years old and has two children: Dennis who is 23 years old and Danica who is 18 years old. Dennis has finished college while Danica still is studying.

Josephine has been a hog raiser in her village for many years. The business contributes a great deal in providing her children with their education. She is hoping to receive a loan of PHP 9,000, which she will use to buy more feed for her hogs.

She hopes to sustain her hog raising while at the same time continuing their rice farming which also helps provide daily necessities, especially in sending their children to school.

loans.use: To buy more feed for her pigs

loans.name: Silva

texts.en:
Silva P. is 44 years old and is living with her five children in Tuburan, Cagayan de Oro City in Northern Mindanao, Philippines. Her husband is a motorcycle driver at their place.

Silva is engaged in buying and selling used clothing or locally known as ukay-ukay. Everyday, she open her stall at her residence to display all the goods she has. Sometimes, Silva makes sidelines to earn extra income: she sells cooked food and peddles it in their village.

Silva is working hard for the primary needs of the family, especially the education of her children.  As of the moment, she is applying for a loan from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. The amount that would be granted to her will be used in procuring additional items for her to sell. Silva is looking forward to a positive response towards her request.

loans.use: To purchase  additional secondhand clothing to sell

location.town: Tuburan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Sebastiana

texts.en:
Sebastiana has been a bites (bread-like rolls) seller in the Kihesa neighborhood of Iringa for three years. She belongs to Dodoma Road C group loan (Group code 2030). She currently earns an average monthly profit of approximately $100. Every day she works at her business for six hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more wheat flour, sugar, cooking oil and charcoal for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.

Sebastiana is 35 years old, married, and has five children: ages 16, 13, 10, 4 and 2.

loans.use: To buy more wheat flour, sugar, cooking oli and charcoal for her business

loans.name: Azra

texts.en:
Azra baji is the wife of M. S. who owes a two-room brick house and has been living in it with her family for the past 15 years. She operates a paranda-making business. A paranda is an item used to tie the hair tightly. Women of Pakistan use them to tie their hair. Azra baji learned this art from her mother.

Azra baji prepares different kinds of parandas, e.g. embroidered and simple. She makes them from thread. Azra baji is applying for a loan to buy material (thread and beads) to increase her profit.

loans.use: To buy thread and beads for her paranda-making business

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia N. and her family live in Villa Marzo Cordon. Lydia is 50 years old and married to Ernesto N.. She is thankful for the blessings she has received from God: having married such a supportive husband, having such good children and being able to run a small enterprise.

Lydia has been a hog raiser for three years and is requesting additional working capital of PHP 8,000 to expand her business. She also helps her husband maintain their rice farm, which is their largest source of income. The couple is grateful because they have been blessed with three children; Jerry is 32 years old, followed by Jerwin who is 31 years old and the youngest is Jermaya who is 24 years old. Unfortunately, Jermaya did not finish her college education due to lack of financial support.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Mayvelyn

texts.en:
Mayvelyn is married to Manuel M. who manages a tricycle transport business. Income from her husband’s business was used to start her hog-raising business. They work together to care for their family and to prepare for the future education of their 8-year-old daughter, Mariuelle, who is currently studying in the elementary school.

Mayyelyn is 35 years old and a good wife and mother who always works hard towards the bettering of her family’s daily living. With regards to their business, Mayvelyn is asking for a loan of PHP 5,000, which will be used to repair the tricycle, their main source of income.

loans.use: To repair her husband's motorcycle tricycle

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina has been a clothes seller and has owned a small charcoal store in the Kihesa neighborhood of Iringa for three years. She belongs to Ngome North group loan (Group code 2032). She currently earns an average monthly profit of approximately $80. Every day she works at her business for twelve hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more charcoal and clothes to sell, so as to expand her business. She is hoping that, through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Amina is 40 years old, married, and has three children: ages 13, 10 and 6. She also cares for three additional dependents.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and clothes to sell

loans.name: Shamim

texts.en: Shamim baji operates a business making paranda. Paranda is an item which is worn by women to tie their hair. Its use has become fashionable. People buy this item as gifts for others. Shamim baji is the wife of L. A. who owns a two-room brick house. They have been living there for the past 15 years. Shamim baji is applying for a loan to buy materials like colored thread and beads for her paranda business.

loans.use: To buy material for making paranda

loans.name: Fulgencio Júlio

texts.pt:
Fulgencio nasceu em gaza, tem 27 anos de idade é solteiro e sem filhos, estudou até a 10ª classe e cursou a formação de professores primários equivalente ao nível medio.

Sai de Gaza para Namaacha uma vila na fronteira da Swazilândia com os seus pais apois a transferencia do seu pai no serviço este que trabalhava na Educaçao. Depois de concluir o ensino basico, a sua mãe aconselhou o para ingressar no curso de formaçao de professores primarios como cominho rapido para entrar no  mercado de emprego. Assim Fulgencio concluiu o curso em dois anos e logo foi afecto para trabalhar como adiministractivo na direcçao distrital de Educaçao na mesma vila de Namaacha, esta a trabalhar como efectivo a tres anos e oufere um salario no valor de 4.700,00mt mensalomente,não consegue poupar nada porque esta a construir a sua rensidencia na vila de Boane que sita a 75 KM de distancia da vila de Namaacha e não consegue concluir, aproxima se a hluvuku solicitando um valor para dar continuidade da sua obra valor este que obteve com um pouco de dificuldades devido a falta de bens, mas com ajuda do seu tio seu avalista  ele consegue superar a barreira e continuar com as obras.  Responsabiliza se pele mae e seus dois irmaos mais novos que vivem na cidade do Maputo enviando lhes 1000,00mt por mês.


Este e o segundo emprestimo de fulgencio na hluvuku e primeiro com kiva. Os primeiros 10.000.00mt foram usados para comprar material de construçao para dar inicio da sua obra pois já possuia uma parte de terra que obteve atraves do stick, e estes outros 10.000.00mt seram usados para dar continuidade da mesma obra. Esta confiante que vai reembolsar antes do tempo determinado e adquirir um outro para mobilar a sua casa.
texts.en:
Fulgencio was born in Gaza Province. He is 27 years old and single with no children. He attended school through the 10th grade and he received training as an elementary teacher.

He left Gaza Province for Namaacha, a town on the border with Swaziland, with his parents after his father was transferred through his work in education. After completing primary education, his mother advised him to enroll in the training course for primary teachers as a fast path to entering the job market. Fulgencio completed the course in two years and quickly went to work as an administrator in the District Administration Office of Education in the same town of Namaacha. He has been working for three years and earns a salary of 4700 meticais monthly. He has not been able to save because he is building his residence in the town of Boane, which is located 75 km away from the town of Namaacha. he has not been able to complete the construction, so he approached Hluvuku requesting a loan to continue the work. He obtained this with a little bit of difficulty due to lack of collateral, but with the help of his uncle as a backer, he was able to overcome this barrier and continue the work. He takes care of his mother and his two younger siblings who live in the city of Maputo by sending them 1000 meticais per month.

This is Fulgencio's second loan from Hluvuku and his first with Kiva. The first 10,000 meticais were used to buy construction material to start the project, since he already has part of the land. This additional 10,000 meticais will be used to continue the same building project. He is confident that he is going to repay before the loan term and take another loan to furnish the house.

Translated from Portuguese by N Aviva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction material

loans.name: Saima

texts.en: Saima C. sells smoked fish at the market and is requesting a loan to buy more smoked fish to sell. She is married to a husband who is a peasant and is 25 years old. Saima has two children who all go to school at Gudele primary school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy land, build a house and rent it out. BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Chhem

texts.en:
A medium-sized wooden house located in Kompong Cham Province belongs to Mrs. Chhem C., age 34, who has been establishing a family with the other family members. She is married with five children who are single, while her husband is a domestic construction worker. She currently earns a living as a local farmer, growing all kinds of vegetables in the village.

The family is facing difficulty with the roof of their house that frequently is cracking during the rainy season. Because of the seasonable problem, Chhem C. is looking for a loan on Kiva to buy zinc to cover their roof. The rest of the loan she will use for her farming business.

loans.use: To buy zinc to cover their roof

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Mrs. Rosario T. has been an active member of Paglaum MPC for three years. She is married and all of her children are already married. Her husband is a carpenter. Only the two of them are living in their home.

Her economic activity is backyard gardening just to help her husband in generating income. Her garden is planted with different kinds of root crops. Her latest loan is intended to purchase fertilizer and pay for labor for soil cultivation.

loans.use: To pay for fertilizer and labor costs for cultivation

loans.name: Brendalee

texts.en:
Being a mother, Brendalee always thinks to secure the future of their children. They sacrifice their time to earn and save for the sake of the future of their children. She is married to Roberto and their family lives in the rural community of Barangay Monguia, Dupax Del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. They have three children: Rodalee, Rozelda, and Rizalee. They want them to finish their studies in college despite the hardships of life.

Farming is their main source of income. They help each other to cultivate their farm. Aside from farming, Brenda is also engaged in buying and selling vegetables in their village. She hopes to borrow PHP 14,000 as additional capital for her business. She really wants to improve her business in order to earn a higher income.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell

location.town: Monguia, Dupax Del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Ratifa

texts.en:
Ratifa, a 44-year-old married mother of five children: ages 16, 14, 13, 10 and 4, also cares for five additional dependents. A member of Ngome north group loan (Group code 2032), Ratifa has owned a small food-vending store in the Kihesa neighborhood of Iringa for five years. Working everyday for 12 hours, she currently earns an average monthly profit of approximately $100.

Ratifa is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania in order to expand her business by purchasing more food items to add to her current stock. She is hoping that through this loan, her profits will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

loans.use: To add more food items to her current stock in order to expand her business.

loans.name: Jenny Joy

texts.en:
“In today’s situation, we must be wise enough in order to survive the current crisis of life,” stated Jenny Joy A.. She is a hardworking mother who aims to become a successful hog-raiser someday and to give her children a better future. She is a faithful housewife to Joselito and they are living in Barangay Monguia, Dupax Del Norte in Nueva Vizcaya. They are blessed with two children: Mark John - 7 years old, and Joshua - 3 years old.

Aside from hog-raising, Jenny is also engaged in the direct-selling business of Avon, Natasha & MSE products. She sells them to her friends and neighbors and in their village. She wishes to borrow PHP 10,000 for her hog-raising and direct-selling businesses. With her perseverance, she knows that she will be able to increase her monthly income and be able to have a more comfortable living condition.

loans.use: As business capital for her hog-raising and direct selling businesses

location.town: Monguia, Dupax Del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe P., a resident of Tipolo, is 35 years old, married, and the mother of two school-aged children. To make a living, Fe operates a family member's business venture in the services sector, primarily providing construction services to local community members. She has been engaged in the business for over four years and earns approximately 6,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Fe joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC used to purchase materials needed to provide service, she is now requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used both to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be Fe’s third loan from PMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Working capital and to purchase additional inventory.

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en:
Nasreen baji is the wife of A. A. who owns a two-room brick house in Kasur city and has been living in it with her family for the last 14 years. Kasur city is famous for its shrines and for its sweetmeats. She is the mother of two daughters. Currently, they are enrolled in school and are getting an education.

Nasreen baji and her husband run a decorative embroidery business. Her husband collects orders from the clothes shops and helps Nasreen baji in her decorative embroidery business. They both prepare embroidered dresses and complete one dress in 15 days and earn 13,000 To 15,000 Pak rupees.

Nasreen baji is applying for a loan to buy material (colored thread, beads and clothes) to complete the orders for preparing embroidered dresses.

loans.use: To buy material for her decorative embroidery business

loans.name: Sheila

texts.en:
Mrs. Sheila G. of Dipolog City, Zamboanga del Norte is widowed and blessed with three children. Now she is a single mom, she strives hard to feed and send to school her three children.

She runs her sari-sari store (variety store) to have an income. Before she began her sari-sari store, she started selling firewood. She is an active member of Paglaum MPC and requested a Php 5,000 loan for additional capital for her business.

loans.use: To purchase groceries for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta is borrowing PHP 7,000 as additional working capital in her general store business in their simple village of Monguia, Dupax Del Norte of Nueva Vizcaya. She is married to Pedro E., and they are blessed with five children. With sacrifices and patience in maintaining their family livelihood, four of their children have already finished their studies in college while her youngest child is still a college student.

Thus, Julieta and her husband are doing their best to earn a higher income. She will use the loan to buy different grocery items and at least two cases of soft drinks that are very much in demand this summer. She is expecting to increase her income with the loan she is hoping to borrow and by working very hard.

loans.use: To buy grocery items for her general store

location.town: Monguia, Dupax Del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Nazia

texts.en:
Nazia baji is the wife of G. H. who owes a two-room brick house and has been living in it with her family for the last 14 years.

She and her husband belong to a decorative embroidery business. Her husband takes orders from the clothes shops and then they both prepare embroidered dresses. They complete one dress in 13 days and earn income.

Nazia baji is applying for a loan to buy material (beads,colored thread and cloth) to complete the orders.

loans.use: To buy material for her decorative embroidery business

loans.name: Wiliamo José

texts.pt:
Wiliamo nasceu em Namaacha uma vila na fronteira de Swazilândia,tem 27 anos de idade e vive maritalmente. E pai de uma filha de 6 anos de idade que se encontra a frequentar a 2 classe.

Wiliamo passou momentos de muitas dificuldades devido a falta de condições dos seus progenitores, então a sua irmã mais velha convida lhe para morar com ela na Swazilândia. Após sua chegada ele inicia com os estudos naquele país e quando já fazia a 3ª classe seu pai manda lhe buscar alegando que o filho não podia viver longe do seu irmão gêmio. Chegado a Namaacha ele consegue ingressar na escola e faz a 10ª classe, devido a sua dedicação na escola  ele é solicitado para trabalhar na rádio comunitaria das cascatas situada na escola secundária como locutor no periodo da tarde das 18:00h as 20:00h auferindo um valor de  1.500.00mt mensalmente. Anos depois entra num projecto de exploração de mel local que foi finaciado pelo governo do distrito de Namaacha  um fundo no valor de 125.000.00mt num grupo de 6 pessoas reembolsando em cada 3 meses um valor de 12.000.00mt  num periodo de 11 mesês mas ele não conseguiu alcançar as suas expectativas devido as mas condições climáticas que se faziam centir, entao aproxima se a hluvuku solicitando um emprestimo no valor de 15.000.00mt para iniciar com seu negócio pessoal de venda de mel adquirido em Inhambane e revendido em Namaacha, tem comprado por viagem 80litros de mel a 150 cada, e revende a 120 o litro tendo assim um lucru mensal de 6.000.00mt  para alem da sua filha wiliamo responsabiliza se pela sua mãe que vive com ela em sua casa.

Este é o terceiro empréstimo de wiliamo na hluvuku e primeiro com kiva. Estes os dois primeiros foram usados para comprar produtos de primeira necessidade para revenda e estes 15.000.00mt seram usados para recomeçar um novo negócio de venda de mel nas comunidades locais. Esta confiante que vai reembolsar antes do tempo determinado e pedir um novo emprestimo para reforçar o seu negócio.
texts.en:
Wiliamo was born in Namaacha, a town bordering Swaziland. He is a 27-year-old married man and has a 6-year-old daughter who is in the 2nd grade. Wiliamo has passed through some difficult times. When he was a child his older sister invited him to live with her in Swaziland. Upon his arrival he began his studies. While attending the 3rd grade his father sent for him, claiming his son could not live so far from his twin brother. When in Namaacha, he managed to enroll in school and later completed the 10th grade. Due to his hard work in school he is solicited for a job at the local community radio station located in the secondary school building as a radio announcer during the hours of 6-8 where he made 1500.00mt monthly. Years later he became involved with a local honey production venture financed by the Namaacha district government. The funding was valued at 125000.00mt for a group of 6 people who were reimbursed every 3 months at 12000.00mt during a period of 11 months. However he was not able to meet these expectations due to poor weather conditions. For this reason he solicits a loan worth 15000.00mt from Hluvuku in order to begin his own business acquiring honey from Inhambane and reselling it in Namaacha. Each trip he purchases 80 liters of honey and resells each liter at 120, obtaining a monthly profit of 6000.00mt. Along with his daughter, Wiliamo is responsible for the care of his mother with whom he resides. This is Wiliamo's third loan with Hluvuku and his first with Kiva. The first two were used to purchases products for resale. The current loan will be used to start a new business selling honey in local communities. He is very confident that he will pay back his loan before the deadline and that he will ask for a new loan to strengthen his business.

Translated from Portuguese by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase and resell honey

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en: Leonida P. lives in Buenavista, Pagadian City, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 53 years old and married. Her husband works as a jail guard. Mrs. Leonida applied for the loan of PHP 14,000 to purchase junk and other scrap materials. One of the richest men in the Philippines started like her, collecting and purchasing junk (used bottles and cans) and other scrap materials (like old newspapers and magazines)from different households and offices and sell these in waste recycling businesses; now he owns prime real properties in the Philippines, Taiwan and Hongkong. His story is always an inspiration for Leonida. The income she generates from her business helps their daily expenses and paying the tuition fees of her children. She plans to have sari-sari store aside from her junk shop.

loans.use: To purchase junk and scrap materials for her junk shop business

loans.name: Azra

texts.en:
My names is Azra. I’m married to M. I. and have resided in a city named Kasur, Pakistan for the past 20 years. Kasur city is famous for its sweetmeats and for its shrines.

Azra baji and her husband have a decorative embroidery business. They prepare embroidered dresses on orders which they collect from the clothes shops. One dress takes 12 days, easily. They have a good number of orders and that’s why Azra baji requires a loan to buy material (beads, colored thread and cloth) to complete the orders on time.

loans.use: To buy decorative embroidery materials

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda, or “Luz” as she is often called in their village, is happily married to Nomer and blessed with two children. They live in Barangay Monguia, Dupax Del Norte of Nueva Vizcaya. Their eldest is now in the third year of high school while the youngest is now in elementary school. They have great ambition for their children and are doing their best to finance their studies.

Luz buys and sells vegetables in their village while her husband is working as a rice and vegetable vendor. According to Luz, she is able to gain a net income of PHP200 per day. She wants to acquire more products; therefore, she is applying for a loan of PHP5, 000 as working capital to improve her vending business.

loans.use: Business capital

location.town: Monguia, Dupax Del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Gelita

texts.en:
Gelita L. is from the town of Mohon, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 50 years old and married. To make a living, Gelita operates a family member's "sari-sari" (local variety) store.

Gelita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gelita is requesting a new loan of 14900 PHP which will be used to purchase stock for sale. This loan will be the fifth taken out by Gelita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional goods for "sari-sari" store business

loans.name: Aparo

texts.en:
Aparo M. is currently selling okra and requests a loan to establish a green vegetable farm on the bank of the Nile River. Thirty years old and married to a driver, Aparo has five children, two boys and three girls, all attending school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To establish a green vegetable farm on the bank of the Nile River.

loans.name: Heang

texts.en: A wooden house in Kompong Cham Province is the location of Mrs. Heang S.'s home and grocery store, a business she has operated since 2005.  This mother of two children, expecting a third within three months, usually purchases produce in bulk on credit from a market supplier, earning an average income of $2.00 per day.  Her husband, On Sar, 26, is a local physician who owns a small pharmacy for selling medicines.  Heang is requesting a loan for her husband to buy additional medicines to meet patients’ needs.

loans.use: To buy additional medicines to meet patients'  needs.

loans.name: Jeremias

texts.en:
Jeremias Q. is from the village of La Victoria, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. He is 37 years old. Jeremias is married and has an infant. To make a living, Jeremias owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for his business comes primarily from selling used shoes in the local community. Jeremias has been engaged in his business for over 3 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Jeremias joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jeremias has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Jeremias is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional used shoes to sell in the local community. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Jeremias from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business and to sustain his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

location.town: La Victoria, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella has had a small shop in the Kihesa neighborhood of Iringa for 4 years. She belongs to Ngome north group loan.  She currently earns an average monthly profit of  approximately $125. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.  

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items to add to her current stock, to improve her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.  Stella is 33 years old, married, and has three children: ages 16, 12, and 9. She also cares for seven additional dependents.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Marylyn

texts.en:
Marylyn T. is from the village of Clarin. She is 44 years old. Marylyn is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Marylyn owns and operates a general store. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Marylyn is just starting this business.

In 2008, Marylyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marylyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Marylyn is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Marylyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To purchase inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Danilo

texts.en: Danilo B. is 41 years old. He and his wife have 7 children.  He lives in Tuburan Cagayan de Oro City. Danilo's primary source of income is through traditional gold mining, locally term pamiling. Danilo wakes up early and go to the pamiling area (near the Tuburan River).  The whole day, under the heat of the sun or even when raining, Danilo pursues his work to earn money. Usually he can bring home 300 to 500 pesos from the gold he mines in a day.  This time, Danilo is applying for a third-cycle loan from HSPFI, a KIVA partner. The amount released to him will be used for the enrollment of his children in school. Danilo is looking forward to spending time as a good member of HSPFI.

loans.use: To enroll his children in school

location.town: Tuburan, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Zeca João Ricardo

texts.pt:
Zeca nasceu em inhambane tem 27 anos de idade estudou ate a 10 classe  vive maritalmente e pai de 2 filhos o rapaz 5 anos e uma rapariga de 2 aninhos somenta o mais velho e que frequenta o centro infantil.

Apois concluir a 10 classe inscreve se para um curso de formaçao de professores onde não foi admitido, anos depois sai de inhambane a maputo onde trabalhava o seu pai pois este havia se divorciado da sua mae. Chegado a maputo seu pai consegue aranjar um emprego nos registo civil como brigadista. Mas devido ao seu desempenho ele foi promovido para categoria de assistente tecnico, e consequentimente e transferido para trabalhar em namaacha uma vila na fronteira da swazilandia, trabalha a mais de 10 anos e aufere por mês um valor de 3.257.00mt valor que não satisfaz as suas necessdades. Mas como queria tanto construir a sua propria casa, aproxima se aos nossos serviços solicitando um emprestimo para dar inicio da sua propria casa que cita a 75km de distancia da vila de namaacha. valor este que pagou com muito sucesso. Para alem dos seus filhos responsabiliza se pela sua mae esta que vive em chimoio enviando lhe em cada 3 meses um valor de 1.000.00mt

Este e o terceiro emprestimo de zeca na hluvuku e primeiro com kiva. Os dois primeiros foram usados para comprar material de construçao para dar inicio da sua obra, estes 15.000.00mt seram usados para concluir  a mesma obra esta cienta que vai reembolsr antes do tempo determinado e pedir um novo para fazer manutençao da sua casa.
texts.en:
Zeca was born in Inhambane and is 27 years old. He completed his studies through the 10th grade. He lives with his wife and is a father of two children, a 5-year-old son and a 2-year-old daughter. The oldest attends preschool.

After completing the 10th grade, he enrolls in a teacher's development course where he was not admitted. Years later he leaves Inhambane for Maputo where his father worked. His father had divorced his mother. When he arrives in Maputo he gets a job in the civil registry. His good performance allowed for his promotion to technical assistant and consequent transfer to Namaacha, a town on the Swaziland border. He has worked for more than 10 years and receives 3257.00mt monthly, a salary that does not allow for a basic living standard. His desire to build his own house has lead him to ask for a loan in order to begin construction 75km outside of Namaacha.

Along with his children he is responsible for the care of his mother with whom he resides in Chimoio. He sends her 1000.00mt every 3 months.

This is Zeca's third loan with Hluvuku and the first with Kiva. The first two were used to purchase construction material to begin work on his house. The loan will be used to finish construction. Zeca believes that he will pay back the loan before the deadline and that he will ask for a new loan to perform maintenance on the house.

Translated from Portuguese by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase construction material

loans.name: Maria Salvida

texts.en:
Maria Salvida lives in the rural village of Monguia Dupax Del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya with her family.  She is married to Rodrigo and gifted with two children: Mark Paolo - 7 years old and Allysa - 4 years old. As a parent, she believes that it is their responsibility to provide their children a better living and a good education.  For this, she and her husband are working hard to sustain their needs.

Salvie patiently raises ducks as their source of income.  Her business is good enough to meet their needs, but it requires a lot of time to take care of the birds.  She is now in need of additional capital of PHP 5,000 that she will use in providing feed for her ducks.  Furthermore, she would like to save for the future of their children through her business and doing her best.

loans.use: To buy feed

location.town: Monguia, Dupax Del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
“Through hard work, we can be successful and survive the hardship of life,” is a simple statement shared by Magdalena, a resident of Barangay Monguia, Dupax Del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. She is married to Julio and with their sacrifices, they have been able to send their children to school. Two of them are now college graduates, while the other two are high school students.  

Her husband works as a farmer, while she is engaged in selling snacks, cooked food, and longganisa (processed meat). The loan she would like to request is around PHP 15,000.  This amount will be used to improve her business by acquiring more products that she can sell.  Magdalena chooses to be patient and humble for she believes it will somehow exalt her business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

location.town: Monguia, Dupax Del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Mavzuna

texts.ru: Дадобоева Мавзуна-41 лет. Вдова и мать 2-х детей. Имеет среднее образование. Занимается продажей женский одежд и материал на рынке Панжшанбе.Так как её муж умер, она растит 2-х детей в одиночку и конечно же ей очень трудно. Мавзуна закупает свой товар из Турции. Мавзуна хотела, бы расширить ассортимент своего товара, потому, что хороший ассортимент привлекает больше клиентов. Для этого она предпочла взять займ для расширения своего ассортимента.
texts.en:
Mavzuna D. is 41 years old, and a widow with two children. She graduated from high school, and sells women's clothing and fabric at the Panjshanbe market. Since the death of her husband, she has raised two children by herself, and that has certainly been difficult. Mavzuna imports her goods from Turkey, and would like to expand the variety of goods she carries, because a broad selection attracts more customers. To this end, she took out a loan to expand her inventory.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Clothing sales

loans.name: Shanlee

texts.en:
Shanlee P. is 31 years old and a resident of Riverside Poblacion, Oroquieta City. Being single and the provider for the family, she has devoted her life to her business as she grew to have her own sales. She has tried snack selling “biko” (a native snack delicacy of Filipinos). Her loyal customers are her relatives, friends, and neighbors. Aside from snack vending, she is venturing into firewood selling as an additional source of income.

Shanlee is in her first year of membership to Paglaum MPC, where she has received working capital. She feels fulfilled. She is applying for PHP 5,000 for additional capital for her snack vending business and firewood selling. Shanlee hopes that one day she will become a big-time business woman.

loans.use: To buy ingredients and inventory

loans.name: Sakina Muhammad Bashir Group

texts.en:
Razia baji wants a loan to buy toys for her toy shop. Kosar baji and Ailas baji each want a loan to buy scrap for their scrap businesses. Sharifan baji wants a loan to buy material (beads, colored thread, and cloth) for her decorative embroidery business.

Sakina baji is the group leader of these five ladies. They all are citizens of a city named Kasur, Pakistan. Kasur city is famous for its sweetmeats and for its shrines. Sakina baji has a very good nature and she is a very hardworking lady. She prepares "Paranda" and sells to the shops. Parandas are famous among women who use it to bind their hair tightly. Her husband's name is M. B., who is a carpenter and makes furniture on order. She is applying for a loan to buy wood so that her husband can complete customers' orders. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy wood

loans.name: Boboto Plus Group

texts.fr: Muteba N. est accoucheuse de formation, elle a une pharmacie qu’elle gère avec son mari dans la partie montagneuse de l’ouest de Kinshasa. Elle a commencé cette activité en 2007 avec un capital de $150. Avec un dur travail et une bonne gestion, Muteba est parvenue à atteindre en 2009 un capital de $300. Elle est cliente fidèle de Hope qui a reçu sept fois les crédits et les a remboursés totalement et à temps. Muteba compte avec le crédit reçu au mois de mai courant, acheter les médicaments à revendre et diversifier son activité en ouvrant une cabine téléphonique. Son affaire génère un bénéfice de $120 par mois. Muteba a l’ambition d’ouvrir un dépôt pharmaceutique. Elle est agée de 52 ans, mariée et mère de dix enfants dont leurs âges varient de 13 à 36 ans. Quatre d’entre eux sont indépendants et les autres sont scolarisés.
texts.en:
Muteba N. is an obstetrician by training. She has a pharmacy she manages with her husband in the mountainous part of western Kinshasa. She started this business in 2007 with $150 in capital. Through hard work and good managing, Muteba managed to reach $300 in capital in 2009. She is a loyal client of Hope, and she has received seven loans and repaid them totally and on time. With the loan received this May, she intends to buy medicines to resell and to diversify her business by opening a phone booth. Her business generates $120 of profit each month. Muteba's ambition is to open a pharmaceutical outlet. She is 52 years old, married, and the mother of ten children, ranging in age from 13 to 36. Four of them are on their own, and the others are in school.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy medicines to resell and to open a telephone booth

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Rosana

texts.en:
Mrs. Rosana G. is a Paglaum member under the PDP-LP program. She has a residence at Caluya, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental.  She is married to Juvy G.. She has been a member of the co-op for almost 1 year. Recently, she has taken a second-cycle loan that will be used as additional capital for her project, which is nipa vending. Regarding her previous loan status, she is a good member and a good payer.

She is planning to acquire land for use as a plantation site for her nipa business so she will be able to directly sell it to the manufacturer in Zamboanga, who buys voluminous amounts of nipa products. She wishes also for her family that her 2 children will be able to finish their college courses and can have a decent job someday.

loans.use: To purchase land

loans.name: Estella

texts.en: Mrs. Estella S., of legal age, is married and blessed with 2 children.  Her husband is a driver and she also manages a sari-sari store business in her home.  She is a member of the Paglaum co-op and is able to maintain her record as a member in good standing.  She accessed a loan from the co-op to capitalize her business, hoping to have a comfortable life in the future.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Munawar Bashir Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Nazia Baji and Shamshad Baji and Razia Baji each want a loan to buy scrap for their scrap businesses. 

Munawar Baji is the wife of B. A. who owns a two-room brick house. She has been living in it with her family for the past 10 years. B. A. runs a scrap business, and Munawar Baji prepares "Parandas," which have become fashionable for women. Parandas are used to tie hair back tightly. She sells parandas to the community and earns income. She is applying for a loan to buy scrap (empty bottles and wasted papers) for her husband's scrap business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.
Note: "Munawar baji is showing its collection of parandas in this picture."

loans.use: To buy scrap (empty bottles and waste paper) for scrap businesses.

loans.name: Nida

texts.en: Mrs. Nida B. is 39 years old and married to Rosito, a driver of their own multi-cab. The couple is blessed with three children and all of them are studying. Her husband has an average monthly income of 2,000 PHP. Nida manages their business. She displays items of bamboo furniture along the highway at their place, and she also delivers furniture in the neighboring municipality and cities during market days. She is happy with her almost decade-long membership with the Paglaum Coop. For now, she requires a loan of $1075 USD for additional capital for her business and for labor costs and materials.

loans.use: To buy bamboo and other materials for furniture making and to cover labor costs.

loans.name: Antoinette

texts.en:
Greetings from Antoinette M., a 39-year-old single woman with one child of 2 years and four orphans she takes care of. They have the following ages: 18, 20, 23, and 24. She lives in the Ngoma district in the western province of Rwanda.

Antoinette M. does her business in Ngoma district where she owns a shop and sells different kinds of merchandise, mostly consumables. She is seeking a loan of $900 USD from Vision Finance Company. She started this business in 2005 and does not have an employee. She starts working at 5:00 A.M. and finishes at 10:00 P.M. every day. Before getting the loan, this entrepreneur earns approximately $90 as a monthly profit.

Ms. M. hopes to expand her business and will reinvest the increased profits in her business. She will also have more savings.

loans.use: Expand the business

loans.name: Bashiran Muhammad Ali Group

texts.en:
Rasheedan baji and Hanifan baji each want a loan to buy wood to sell.

Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy decorative material (beads, colored thread and clothes).

Sugran baji wants a loan to buy cotton to sell.

Mumtaz baji wants a loan to buy beams for her shuttering business.

Rehana kosar baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her fruit-selling business.

Bashiran baji is the wife of M. A. who has lived in a city named Kasur, Pakistan for the past ten years. Kasur city is famous for its sweetmeats and for its shrines. Her husband runs a construction supplies business and has three years of experience in this business.

Bashiran baji is the group leader of the above mentioned ladies. She operates a decorative embroidery business. She prepares embroidered dresses on orders which she collects from her community. She is applying for a loan to buy construction supplies to increase her husband’s profit.

loans.use: To buy construction supplies to increase her husband's profit

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Mrs. Lolita N., 36 years old, is a resident of Lapasan, Clarin, Mis. Occ. She is married and blessed with four children and her husband is a motorcab driver. Three of her children are already enrolled in the elementary grade and the other one is still a minor dependent.

In order to help her family, she decided to engage in business. Now she has a sari-sari store (variety store) which she opened in October 2008 with an initial capital of only P2,000 with her neighbors as her first customers. To increase her capital, she is applying for an amount of P14,500 as her 3rd loan obtained under the PDP-LP program of Paglaum MPC – Ozamiz Branch. Her future plan for her business is to have a mini grocery store someday. She is also hoping that she can provide a better future for her children.

loans.use: As additional capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Inocencia

texts.en:
Mrs. Inocencia R., 48 years old, is a widow and lives at Tubod, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She has five children. Because she could not get a good job, she decided to sell dried fish and vegetables for a living.

With the family's financial difficulties, Inocencia joined Paglaum MPC to obtain financial assistance. But she was also happy knowing that she will also be able to save part of her income and obtain other benefits offered by the cooperative. Now, she requests PHP 14,900 for additional capital to buy dried fish and vegetables. Her greatest desire is to see her children finish their studies and live a comfortable life ahead.

loans.use: To buy additional dried fish and vegetables for sale

loans.name: Lorivic

texts.en:
Lorivic A. is from the village of Taboc Sur, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental in the Philippines. She is 24 years old and married. To make a living, Lorivic owns and operates a retail business called a "sari-sari," or general store. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. Lorivic has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately $150 USD a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lorivic joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lorivic is requesting a new loan of $100 USD which will be used to purchase additional products to sell in her "sari-sari." This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lorivic from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business and to support her family's financial needs.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Lalang

texts.en: Lalang R., a 35 year old woman, sells tomatoes and okra and is requesting a loan to open up a shop. Her husband is a peasant and they have three children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent. BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open a shop

loans.name: Cresencia

texts.en:
Mrs. Cresencia A., 45 years of age, has been an active member of Paglaum Coop for years. She is engaged in raising pigs in her backyard.

Being a member of the coop, she is very diligent and, in fact, obtained financial assistance from the coop several times. Now another loan has been released to her in the amount of Ph 12,000 intended for the purchase of feed and medicine for her swine. She is hoping to have a comfortable life in the future.

loans.use: To purchase of feed and medicine for her pigs

loans.name: Saodat

texts.ru: Зикриёева Саодат- женшина 42 лет. Замужем имеет 3-х детей. Она занимается продажей детских одежд. Она торгует на рынке Панчшанбе города Худжанда. В пятницу она выходит на рынок «Джума-базар», а в воскресенье на рынок «Якшанбе-базар». Саодат закупает товар в городе Бишкек Республики Кыргизистан. Она ездит за товаром 1 раз в месяц. Ей помогает старшая дочка Нилуфар. Саодат хочет расширит свой товар и открыть ещё одну точку продажи.
texts.en:
Saodat Z. is a 42-year-old woman, who is married and has three children. She sells children's clothing at the Panchshanbe market in the town of Khujand. She goes to the Juma bazaar on Fridays, and on Sundays to the Yakshanbe bazaar. Saodat imports her goods from Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan, where she goes on a buying trip once a month. Her eldest daughter Nilufar helps her. Saodat wants to expand the selection of goods she carries and to open an additional sales outlet.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Children's clothing

loans.name: Tuwe Wamoja Group

texts.en:
Asha has been a clothes and tea bag seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for four years. She belongs to Tuwe wamoja group loan (Group code 2067).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of approximately $90. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.  


She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes and tea bags for resale and improve her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.  


Asha is 40 years old, married, and has given birth to seven children. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Zaituni, Zuhura, Mmanga and Blestina. Each woman also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and tea bags for resale

loans.name: Khadija

texts.en:
Khadija has been a bed sheet and soap seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for one year. She belongs to Wastara group loan (Group code 2006).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of approximately $40. Every day she works at her business for 10 hours.  


She is requesting a loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more bed sheets and soap for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.  


Khadija is 32 years old, married, and has given birth to an 11-year-old child. She also cares for two dependents.

loans.use: To buy more bed sheets and soap

loans.name: Pascuala

texts.en: Pascuala D., 59 years old, engages in peanut vending.  She lives in Pinig, Dumalinao, Zamboanga Del Sur.  Her husband works in their village as a janitor.  Pascuala applied for a loan worth PHP 5,000.00 to purchase peanuts, brown sugar, cooking oil and cellophane.  Her business helps with their daily expenses.  She delivers her finished product to Dumalinao town every market day.  She plans to expand her peanut delivery in Pagadian City in order to generate more income.

loans.use: Purchase 3 sacks of peanuts, 10 kls of brown sugar, cooking oil

loans.name: Prescilla

texts.en:
"In everything you do, put God first and you will somehow (be) directed and someday become successful,” said Prescilla D. V. of Barangay Monguia, Dupax Del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. She is married to Villamore and they were blessed with eight children. Being responsible parents, six of their children have already graduated from college and the youngest two are still studying. They want to give them the best education they can because it is the only treasure that they are able to give to their children. Hence, they are striving hard to support the studies of their two children.

Her husband cultivates their small farm for two cropping seasons, planting rice and vegetables, while Prescilla is engaged in the vending business of food to help her husband support the education of their two children. She wanted to borrow a loan from lenders amounting to PHP12,000 as additional working capital. She will use the loan to improve her enterprise. She hopes to become successful by utilizing the loan wisely and by persevering toward the development of her business.

loans.use: Business capital

location.town: Monguia, Dupax Del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Carlita

texts.en: Mrs. Carlita A. lives in Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 25 years old and has been a member of PMPC-Microfinance for two years. She has only one child, who lives with them and studies at the elementary level. She has a happy family with her husband and child. The loan she seeks now is for her ninth cycle in the amount of PHP 12,500.00 to buy food for the fish in her fish pond. Her future plan for her business is to have a good harvest. She is thankful that her life now is quite good.

loans.use: Additional capital for her fish pond

loans.name: Rafonzel

texts.en: Rafonzel D. is a single resident of Dapitan City, Zamboanga del Norte. She has been a member of Paglaum Coop for almost two years and has had four loans. She operates an eatery beside the sea port.  Her last loan was used to purchase more stocks of meat, fish, spices and other ingredients for her business, hoping to alleviate her life of hard work.

loans.use: Purchase meat, fish and spices for eatery

loans.name: Jowakir

texts.en:
Jowakir J. currently sells plastic plates at the shop and is requesting a loan to stock more goods in her shop to sell. She has six children and married a nurse. In the future, Jowakir wants to open up another shop for selling the same items but in a different location or market.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more goods to sell

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena and Alain P. raise their family in a peaceful community located at Barangay Monguia, Dupax Del Norte in the province of Nueva Vizcaya. Both of them are only high school graduates since their parents could not afford to finance their studies in college. In this regard, they plan to send their three children to college for they don’t want them to follow in their steps. They are doing their best to make their ambitions a reality.

Alain, who is her husband, is engaged in the hog-raising business while Rowena manages their sari-sari store (typical community based store) at home. She sells groceries, soft drinks and vegetables. She is applying for a loan of PHP 5,000 for her store. She acquires most of her selling products in Bambang Public Market. Rowena is thankful for having at least PHP200 daily income from her business and now she wishes to increase it in the coming days through the support of the lenders.

loans.use: Business Capital

location.town: Monguia, Dupax Del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en: Mrs. Daisy B. D. has been a Paglaum member under the PDP-LP program for almost one year and one month. She resides at Caluya, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis, Occidental and is married to Romulo D.. She's in good standing and currently she's requesting her second loan for additional capital for her business, which is nipa vending. If it is God's will, she plans to buy her own boat that her husband will use in fishing. And for her family, she wishes that her children will able to finish their school through college.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Meriam

texts.en:
Meriam B. is from the village of San Vicente Bajo, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She is 41 years old. Meriam is married. To make a living, Meriam owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector: a "sari-sari store" or general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, etc. in the local community. Meriam has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from this activity.

In 2009, Meriam joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Meriam is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell in her "sari-sari store". This loan will be the first loan taken out by Meriam from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies for herself and for her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en: Mrs. Nancy V., 47 years of age, is married with two children.  Her major activity is selling fish and raising pigs in her backyard. Her husband's major activity is fishing.  She has been an active member of Paglaum co-op for 3 years and already accessed financial support from the co-op for several times.  She has requested another loan to purchase fishing materials and repair of their pump boat including labor costs.

loans.use: purchase fishing materials; pumpboat parts and  labor

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en: Mrs. Carmelita E. is 41 years old, married to Ricardo E. and blessed with 4 children. She is a bona fide resident of Punta Sulong, Baliangao Misamis Occidental. Recently, she's accessed her 4th loan for additional capital for her existing project.

loans.use: additional capital for her fish cage

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en:
Tabitha C. sells beans, green vegetables, and flour and is requesting a loan to stock more beans and flour to sell. She is 39 years old and married to a driver. Tabitha has three children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for the family to live in. BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock more beans and flour to sell

loans.name: Milca

texts.en: Milca H. is a 55-year-old, married with 2 children; she lives in Panaon, Mis Occ.  She started her business when she joined Paglaum.   She sells such things as pots, clothes, slippers, and other items.  Milca is trying hard for them to live comfortably with Paglaum MPC as her financing partner.

loans.use: To buy additional stock for her business

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha has been a clothes seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for five years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of approximately $70. Daily she works at her business for twelve hours. She belongs to Maisha bora group loan (Group code 2101).

Asha is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes for resale to expand her business. She is hoping that, through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, save money for future use and improve her home.

Asha is 29 years old, and married. She takes care of three dependents.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale

loans.name: Bavi Dani El Group

texts.en:
Rani baji wants a loan to buy wheat to sell.

Veenus baji wants a loan to buy goats for her animal-selling business.

Rasoolan baji and Sugran baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shops.

Bavi baji is the group leader of the above mentioned four ladies. They all belong to a city named Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. Bavi baji is a very hardworking lady. She operates a business sewing clothes to pay off the utilities of her house. She and her husband share the financial burden so they live happy and fight with the circumstances.

Her husband sells construction supplies and has three years of experience in this business. Bavi baji is applying for a loan to buy construction supplies to complete the orders of her husband’s customers because nowadays he is out of stock.

loans.use: To buy construction supplies for her husband's business

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en:
Mrs. Shirley O., 50 years of age, is the mother of twelve children with eight of them still her dependents and students.

She buys fish of different kinds from various fishermen and she dries all the fish and sells it in the market. Her economic activity is the one that feeds all her children and sends them to school. She deeply wishes that her business will flourish and hopes to continually support her family's needs.

loans.use: To purchase the materials for a fishing boat

loans.name: Manzura

texts.ru: Манзура - пожилая женщина 1944 года рождения. Вдова и имеет 8-х детей. Манзура живет с двумя младшими сыновьями. Манзура откармливает скот дома, и когда скот будет готов, сын Манзуры продает их на скотном рынке. Манзура кредитуется в нашей организации 2 года. Она успешно закончила 4 предыдущих займов, и теперь хочет взять очередной займ. Манзура планирует увеличить количество своего скота и тем увеличить прибыль своей семьи. Манзура очень нравится условия нашего кредитования, и она рада, что есть такие организации, поддерживающие общество.
texts.en:
Manzura is an older woman, who was born in 1944. She is a widow with eight children, and lives with her two youngest sons. Manzura raises cattle at home, and when the cattle are ready, her son sells them at the livestock market. Manzura has been a loan customer at MicroInvest for two years, has successfully repaid four previous loans, and now would like another loan. She is planning to increase the size of her herd and thus increase her family's profits. Manzura is pleased with the terms of MicroInvest's loan program, and happy that there are such organizations supporting the public.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising and selling cattle

loans.name: Wennie

texts.en: Wennie S. is from the town of Butuay, Jimenez. She is 50 years old, married and has three adult children. Wennie owns and operates a "carenderia" (restaurant), primarily serving local foods to customers in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2004, Wennie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,950 PHP from PMPC and is now requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase food & drinks for the restaurant. This loan will be her 11th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy food and soft drinks for her carenderia

loans.name: Jemelita

texts.en:
"I have only a one hectare (2.5 acre) farm. This has helped me in providing for the needs of my children. We started by sowing corn. I was a tenant back then until we were able to buy our own farm. I am planning to buy a carabao (a domesticated subspecies of the water buffalo) in the future to be able to sustain our livelihood," says Mrs. Jemelita O., 32-year old mother of two children.

She would like a loan of Php 7,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase fertilizer and hybrid corn seed. The loan will truly help her get a better income for her family. She is now looking for some other possible income areas to contribute better to the family income.

Through CEVI, Mrs. O. is able to sustain her corn farm. She receives not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and hybrid corn seed

loans.name: Shafique Rafiq Group

texts.en:
Shafique wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Munir, Jamila and Nasreen want loans to buy buffaloes for their milk selling business.

Shafique is the group leader. Her husband, R. runs a dairy business. Presently, they have one buffalo but now she is applying for a loan to buy another buffalo to increase the profit of her dairy business. They are citizens of Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan.

This is a group loan. Loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee the entire loan. If one member does not repay, other members are responsible.

loans.use: Buy a buffalo for dairy business.

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha has been an animal keeper and owned of a small shop in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 10 years. She belongs to the Fadhlat group (Code 2104). She earns an average monthly profit of approximately $40. Every day she works for 10 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so she can buy more cosmetics and salon items to add her current stock, to improve her business. She is hoping that her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Aisha is 30 years old, married, and has six children: ages 14, 13, 10, 7 and one year old twins. She also cares for two additional dependents.

loans.use: Buy cosmetics and salon items to sell to improve her business.

loans.name: Patrocenio

texts.en:
Patrocenio P., 28, is from the village of Mialen Clarin Misamis Occidental. He is married and has two infant-aged children.

To make a living, Patrocenio owns and operates a general store. His main source of income comes from selling a variety of products in the local community. Patrocenio has been in business for over three years and earns approximately 1000 PHP a month. He is also a "pedicab driver" or motorcycle driver.

In 2007, Patrocenio joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to improve his living situation and engage in business activities. Patrocenio has successfully repaid a loan of 12000 PHP from GDMPC.

Patrocenio is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to purchase products to sell. This loan will be his fourth. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the living conditions of his family.

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

loans.use: Purchase products to sell.

loans.name: Jacinita

texts.en:
Jacinita M. is a member in good standing of Paglaum MPC of Progressive Center Calaran, Calamba, Misamis Occidental.

She's been a member for almost nine years. Currently, she's availing her sixth cycle for additional capital for hog raising, to purchase sacks of feeds for two pig's daily consumption.

Jacinita is very thankful to our Almighty God that there's an institution like Paglaum Cooperative who helps her a lot in terms of financial assistance.

loans.use: Purchase feed.

loans.name: Reneda

texts.en:
Reneda Q. is from the village of Gala Ozamiz. She is 55 years old, married and has eight adult-aged children.

To make a living, Reneda grows and sells flowers in the local community. Reneda has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month.

In 2005, Reneda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. Reneda has successfully repaid a previous loan from GDMPC.

Reneda is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional flowers to sell. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Reneda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve/expand the business and to support her family.

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

loans.use: Purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Razia Aslam Group

texts.en:
